title: brexit deal vote house of commons theresa may
story: The PM will hold a second vote on her Brexit deal tomorrow - and is expected to suffer a heavy loss after talks with Brussels collapsed.But in a last-minute bid to win over Brexiteers, Mrs May is reportedly now planning to fly to Strasbourg - home of the European Parliament - for talks with top Eurocrats Jean-Claude Juncker and Michel Barnier.The PMs plans were announced by Irish foreign minister Simon Coveney who said Mrs May was going to try and finalise an agreement,thats possible.No sources said the travel plans were not confirmed.After Attorney General Geoffrey Cox failed to secure legally binding changes to the Irish backstop proposal last week, the PM has come under pressure to abandon the second meaningful vote on the deal.Tory MPs urged her instead to hold a symbolic motion on whether to approve the deal subject to a set of specic changes.But other senior figures warned theyd kick her out of officeshe chickened out of the meaningful vote.Today Brexit minister Robin Walker confirmed the vote would go ahead as originally planned - as well as the two other votes on delaying Brexit and going for No Deal,her deal is rejected.Mr Cox will publish his full legal advice tomorrow morning before the start of debate on the deal.Top Brexiteer Nigel Evans told The Sun: Its pointless putting the same deal to a vote, that would be the worst-case scenario for her.The cleverest thing for Theresa is to drag back control by postponing the vote.He urged the PM to hold her nerve and keep pushing the EU for concessions right up to the March  deadline when were due to quit the EU.Jacob Rees-Mogg told The Times: “I think a meaningful vote with an addendum saying this House will support a dealsuch and such is done might be a way of uniting the party or limiting the scale of the defeat.And Mark Francois, another senior member of the European Research Group, said: Why come back to the House of Commons to be thumped again, what does that achieve Last month Mrs May promised to hold the binding vote on her deal by March  - and said thatshe lost, MPs would be able to decide what happens next.According to the current timetable, the Commons would vote on Wednesday on whether or not to leave the EU without a deal on March .MPs would then have a chance to delay Brexit by up to three months in a further vote on Thursday.Ex-minister Nick Boles hinted he would vote to bring down the Government and trigger a snap electionthe PM went back on her vow.He tweeted: I am sure that the Prime Minister will honour these three commitments. If she doesnt she will forfeit the confidence of the House of Commons.Leading moderates have called on the PM to quither strategy flops this week.Today senior Tory George Freeman said Mrs Mays days were numbered evenshe does pull off a victory in tomorrows vote.He told the BBC: I hope the Prime Minister can get withdrawal through and then I do think we need to choose a new leader for a new generation with a new vision of a conservativism that can make sense of Brexit and reinspire and reunite the nation.Allowing the Commons to choose between No Deal and a Brexit delay could tear the Government apart and see at least a dozen ministers resign.Last night Health Minister Steve Brine said he would quittold to vote for a No Deal Brexit.He called on Mrs May to offer Tory MPs a free votethe motion does take place.David Cameron today backed the PMs strategy - but warned against a possible No Deal.Questioned outside his London home, the former Prime Minister said: I support the Prime Minister and I think she is doing the right thing seeking a partnership deal with the EU, thats the right approach.And he added: I dont think No Deal is a good idea at all.

title: business brexit deal delay house of commons
story: Industry groups told The Sun businesses are desperate for a resolution to the Brexit debate.They expressed support for Theresa Mays Brexit deal so Britain can finally leave the EU on March .And they suggested the best way to rule out a chaotic No Deal was to vote for the withdrawal agreement in tomorrows crunch Commons showdown.A spokesman for the Confederation of British Industry said: If a deal is secured, that would at least give businesses the certainty theyre desperate for.The Institute of Directors added: A majority of our members want to avoid No Deal - that means supporting Mays deal, because thats the only way to do it.Stephen Jones, head of UK Finance, told The Sun: “Time is running out to avoid a chaotic No Deal Brexit that would do signicant damage to the UK economy.Every day of uncertainty means more damage to investment, jobs and business confidence.And Mike Cherry of the Federation of Small Businesses said: “Over the next week, small businesses need to see Parliament come together and map a credible route towards a pro-business deal that delivers the transition period they crave.There is no more time for political games.If the PMs deal is defeated today, the Commons is expected to vote for a delay to Brexit of up to three months.But bosses warned a delay is pointlessit means just kicking the can down the road.A spokesman for the British Chambers of Commerce said: It cant just be delay for the sake of delay, it has to be with an idea of what happens next.The British Retail Consortium said retail firms are spending cash on contingency plans because they dont know what shape Brexit will take.The group said: A delay would increase theof time theyre spending that money to prepare for No Deal.Tomorrow the House of Commons will vote on whether to accept the Prime Ministers deal.If it is defeated, MPs will then be given the choice between leaving with No Deal on March , or delaying Brexit instead.

title: esther mcvey deletes embarrassing untrue
story: NewsEsther McVey deletes embarrassing untrue Brexit tweet hours after defending itShe posted a link to a four year old article which claimed all EU member states will be forced to adopt the Euro, which they wontShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tory Esther McVey has deleted an untrue claim about EU member states being forced to accept the Euro - after initially defending it on Twitter .The former Work and Pensions Secretary provoked outrage on Sunday after she tweeted untrue claims made in a  newspaper opinion column as fact. The original article, published in the , claimed all EU member states would be forced to accept the Euro single currency after . There is no evidence that this is the case. The four-year-old article’s claims were linked to by anti-EU blog BrexitCentral, which was then retweeted by Ms McVey. She wrote: “Are the public aware of this  And the many other things the EU has planned for its member states after   #trust #watchout”   The tweet came just hours after Ms McVey had tweeted to complain that trust in politicians was at an “all time low”. After a deluge of replies to her tweet, many asking whether she believed MPs posting bafflingly untrue statements had any bearing on the public’s trust in politics, Ms McVey released another dazzling display of social media point-missing, appearing to suggest facts were something that one could “agree” or “disagree” with. She wrote: “From reading the comments, evenyou don’t agree with the article I posted, I think we can all agree on one thing - we never want the UK to join the Euro. True or  ” Ms McVey has since deleted the original tweet which included the link to the article. But savvy social media users took screenshots of it, to secure its place in the history books.

title: john mcdonnell blames philip hammonds
story: NewsJohn McDonnell blames Philip Hammonds Brexit cowardice for gloomy economyHe accused Theresa May of a "brutal complacency" to the inequalities in societyShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPhilip Hammond’s “cowardice” over Brexit is to blame for Britain’s gloomy economic forecasts, John McDonnell said today.And he said Theresa May had a “brutal complacency” to the inequalities in society. Labour ’s Shadow Chancellor accused his Tory opposite number of “abdicating his responsibility” as chancellor to protect the economy.And he claimed claimed slow economic growth, falling investment and firms announcing their intention to leave the UK were all avoidable were it not for the political weakness and cowardice of the Chancellor. He said Mr Hammonds failure to stand up for the economy and the interests of the country were to blame.   Askedhe thought the Prime Minister had also been cowardly, he told the Mirror: “In terms of my description of Theresa May, best not in public really. “The thing that defines Theresa May I think, and Philip Hammond is almost a brutal complacency on what’s been happening in our society. A brutal complacency. “But you combine that with incompetence and it’s the worst of all worlds. “So we have turning a blind eye to the real suffering of our people, and at the same time being totally incompetent at managing the basic elements of government.” He added: “I don’t think we’ve ever been in this situation.”   In a speech at Bloomberg ahead of Wednesdays Spring Statement, Mr McDonnell said: The position of the Chancellor of the Exchequer comes with a responsibility which I think Philip Hammond actually has abdicated in his current role.If Brexit ends up leading to even half of what the Governments own forecasts suggest could happen, I think history will judge harshly the few who could have prevented and averted this potential disaster and did so little.He said the effects of their complicity are already there, including the slowest growth in six years, investment falling, manufacturing in recession, a trade deficit of over pound billion last quarter, growth forecasts being revised downwards by the Bank of England and others ... firms announcing their intentions to leave the UK. I think all this was avoidable were it not for the political weakness and yes, these are strong words, the cowardice of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, he said. Failure to stand up for our economy and failure to stand up for the interests of our country. And whatever happens with Brexit, thats damage to peoples lives that cannot be undone.   The Chancellor is due to deliver his Spring Statement to the Commons on Wednesday afternoon. Mr McDonnell predicted the speech would include warm words about the need to avoid a no-deal Brexit. He said while there may be more rhetoric about the end of austerity, there would be nothing to relieve the suffering of millions out there today - or to prepare us for tomorrow. Mr McDonnell said: This is a week where we say no more. Where we will lay bare the failures of this Government and the damage it has done to our society. But also where we will seek in Parliament a route through the Brexit chaos that the Government has created and an end to austerity once and for all.

title: karate gruffalo brexit tory leadership
story: NewsKarate, The Gruffalo and Brexit - Tory leadership hopeful Dominic Raab gives nakedly-ambitious speechThe former Cabinet Minister delivered a highly-personal address to the Onward think tankShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  MAR NewsHe didnt even deny he was interested "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of the Tory MPs tipped to succeed Theresa May said “never say never” when askedhe wants to be Prime Minister today. Ex-Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab fuelled claims he is paving the way for a tilt at the leadership in a wide-ranging speech aimed squarely at Conservative activists. In a highly-personal address, he spoke about reading The Gruffalo childrens book to his two young sons, revealed how his Jewish refugee father battled to get him into a grammar school after he “flunked” the initial exam just hours after his sister suffered a serious car crash, and boasted of his karate skills.  The speech, to the centre-right Onward think tank, was seen as a naked bid for the top job when Brexit-battered Mrs May finally quits No. “The Prime Minister has said she wont lead us into the next election and I think she deserves the time and space to depart on terms of her own choosing,” he said. Asked directlyhe wants to be PM, he quipped: “Never say never.” Mrs May faces another major test tomorrow when MPs hold a second “meaningful” vote on the withdrawal deal, two months after the PM suffered a humiliating -vote defeat.

title: universal credit dwp should pay
story: NewsUniversal Credit: DWP should pay compensation for late payments, report declaresThe call is all the more striking because its been issued by a liberal Conservative aligned think tankShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR NewsThe major policy sht could have helped hundreds of thousands of people who have not received their first payment on time "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Department for Work and Pensionsmust pay out compensation to families who receive their Universal Credit late, a report declares today.The major policy sht could have helped hundreds of thousands of people who have not received their first payment on time. As of February , a shocking % of Universal Credit claimants did not receive their first payment on time and in full. The standard waiting time for the benefit, paid to .million claimants and counting, is five weeks. The recommendation is made by the liberal Conservative-leaning think tank Bright Blue in a major report on reforming UC.  The groups report, Helping Hand  Improving Universal Credit, calls for an Independent Case Examiner to examine cases the DWP has handled wrongly. The case examiner could set standards for the DWP, such as delivering payment on time, as well as standards for the claimants. The amount of compensation issued to UC claimants should to some degree mirror the amount lost by claimants because of sanctions, Bright Blue said. Specically, the financial compensation offered to claimants as a result of non-compliance by DWP should be tiered according to the number of weeks a claimant has waited for their UC award. The Bright Blue report also recommended the DWP introduce a UC phone app and a live chat facility, and cap the number of claimants dealt with by each work coach.   The think tank said a certain amount of overpayments by the DWP should be disregardedthe government made the mistake. And it recommended a relaxing of the Minimum Income Floor, a cap on benefits for self-employed claimants that is currently being challenged in the High Court.  Ryan Shorthouse, Director at Bright Blue and co-author of the report, said: “Universal Credit has plenty of potential. A majority of claimants are coping with and adapting to Universal Credit. There are positive experiences with work coaches. And there are positive attitudes too: especially towards the single payment model and the use of conditionality. “However, as it has gone from idea to implementation, the initial widespread support Universal Credit enjoyed has dissipated. Despite welcome improvements made by the Government in recent years, there are too many examples and too much evidence of signicant hardship experienced by a sizable minority of those on Universal Credit.” A DWP spokesperson said: “We welcome the report’s finding that the majority of people have had a smooth move onto Universal Credit, appreciating the simple monthly payment and work coach support. “Universal Credit is a force for good, supporting over . million people. The majority of claimants are happy with the service and where challenges remain, we will continue to make improvements.”

title: brit couple face 140k singapore
story: NewsBrit couple face £k Singapore hospital bill after mum suddenly gives birth earlyChloe Wilkinsons travel insurance did not cover the unexpected birth of little baby Lorcan during a stopover in SingaporeShareCommentsByLouie Smith:,  MAR NewsThe couple were planning to tell their parents about the pregnancy once home - but little Lorcan wasnt waiting"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British couple stranded in Singapore face a poundk hospital bill after their baby was born premature at  weeks. Chloe Wilkinson, , and Patraic Walsh-Kavanagh, , were travelling back to the UK to tell their parents about the surprise pregnancy. But Chloe went into labour during a stopover in Singapore and gave birth to their son Lorcan, who weighed just .lbs. He is currently in intensive care and will have to stay in hospital for at least the next three months.    Chloe and Patraic took out travel insurance ahead of their once-in-a-letime trip, which began in December . But the policy didnt cover the unexpected pregnancy. Teaching assistant Chloe said: Lorcan’s been fighting with all his might and we are bursting with pride at the strength he is showing so far. “However, we are on our own, a  hour flight away from our family and friends, and it has been a very dficult start to parenthood whilst Lorcan remains in hospital.    Its still such a huge shock to us both that hes here but were doing everything we possibly can to ensure we all get back to the UK. Patraic added: We were in a complete state of shock and fear completely took over as we were faced with a severely premature baby with potentially multiple health issues whilst being stuck in a country with no support. “On top of this I was handed an estimated bill of poundk [, SGD] assuming there will be no further complications with Chloe or the baby. Teaching assistant Chloe and Patraic left the UK in December  to go travelling around Asia.    They then found work together in Australia before discovering Chloe was pregnant last November. The couple, who wanted to tell their parents the news in person, began flying home last month. But during a two-day stopover in Singapore Chloe was rushed to hospital after experiencing bleeding and cramps. Doctors told her she had started dilating at just  weeks - meaning flying home was no longer an option. Patraic, from Nottingham, East Mids, said: All the doctors and nurses seemed very concerned.   After numerous tests it was found that she had an infection so she was started on antibiotics and medication to reduce contractions and prolong labour to give baby the best chance of survival. However, Chloe, from Lincoln, fell more seriously ill and medics decided they had to deliver Lorcan immediately. She said: I was absolutely terried because I knew it was too early. When my water broke the room was quickly filled with doctors, midwives and paediatricians As soon as he was delivered he went straight into an incubator where the paediatricians started to help him breathe and stabilise him before whisking him off to intensive care. Hes fighting and doing his best but we feel so helpless.    Lorcan is currently in intensive care while his parents are living in a shared flat near the hospital. Their lack of working visas means they are unable to seek employment to support themselves. So the couple are trying to raise as close to pound, on GoFundMe to help pay for Lorcans hospital bills. By Monday afternoon they had raised more than pound,. Chloe added: Were professional people who work hard but its obviously a huge sum and anything anyone can offer to help would be greatly appreciated. We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone at home and across the world for their continued love and support. The travel insurer has been approached for comment.Anyone wishing to help the couple can visit their Go Fund Me page

title: distraught mums home invaded rats
story: NewsDistraught mums home invaded by rats as experts warn amateur poisons wont workLaura McQueenie, from Edinburgh, claims two rats have died in her kitchen sinkShareCommentsByArthur VundlaKelly-Ann Mills:,  MAR NewsMum Laura McQueenie has spotted rats throughout her flat "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA distraught mum claims her home has been invaded by rats, as experts warn the rodents are immune to some poisions. Mum-of-three Laura McQueenie has been plagued by the germ-carrying animals at her council flat in Niddrie, Edinburgh, where she lives with her sons and young niece. The -year-old said the living conditions were disgraceful and describing overflowing bins as a health hazard. After the birth of her youngest son seven months ago, the social work student began to realise the scale of the problem. Laura said: Two rats have died in my kitchen sink and there are many more we have seen.   Every evening I hoover and sanitise all surfaces before bed. When I wake in the morning there are rat droppings all over the kitchen workspaces, window sill – they are even inside the bread bag. There are droppings all over the living room window sills, the floors. The young mum lives with her sons, aged eight, two and seven months, as well as her -month old niece. Laura said problems with rats were affecting the health of her youngest child - and said poison poured into the rodents’ holes did nothing to solve the problem. “The flat is absolutely disgraceful and it’s disgusting that we have to stay here because there’s nowhere  suitable for us. It’s been horric living here and it’s heartbreaking that I have no other option.   “I now go to my mum’s during the day because I can’t bear to be there. It’s filthy. The bins outside are a severe health hazard and I’ve been down with rubber gloves trying to clean some of it.” Pest control firm Wee Critters Pest Control estimated that there was a  per cent increase in call-outs year on year, while owner Sylvia Hill said amateur poisons bought by concerned residents would barely make a dference to the problem. Sylvia believes the Gorgie area of Edinburgh could be the worst in Scotland for rat infestations - and described the problem as a plague. She said: “We are struggling with the high demand at the moment. Ive had to share some of our jobs with other pest control companies. The city centre is full of rat problems but Gorgie is the worst area by far and possibly the worst in Scotland. We are honestly never out of there. Some of the problems are caused by laziness to be honest.   Rather than opening the bin lid to throw away the rubbish, people are leaving their rubbish and dog poo at the side of their bins.” She added: I have seen people buying amateur rat poison but although it may kill a mouse or two, adult mice and rats are hardly affected by it. The rats are just a major issue in Edinburgh at the moment. A total of , pest control requests were received by the City of Edinburgh Council last year with the Forth, Sighthill Gorgie and Craigentinny Duddingston wards proving to be the most problematic areas of the city. And there were , complaints about missed bin collections. However, although it appears that the rat population is increasing, the local authority said it had not experienced a signicant increase in vermin callouts. Cllr Lesley Macinnes, convener for Transport and Environment, said: We remain surprised by these comments and would be interested in hearing from the pest control firm, as this information goes against our evidence of what is happening in the city.

title: four year olds terrifying 5
story: NewsFour-year-olds terrying  words before she stopped breathing and turned blueScottish politician Alex Cole-Hamiltons little girl Darcy was watching YouTube when she suddenly swallowed a  cent Euro coin last nightShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsAlex Cole-Hamiltons four-year-old daughter Darcy swallowed a coin last night "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA four-year-old girl watching YouTube uttered five terrying words to her dad before she stopped breathing and changed colour. Scottish politician Alex Cole-Hamiltons daughter Darcy swallowed a  cent Euro coin as she sat happily in her pyjamas last night.The MSP heard an awful strangulated scream, before his little girl said: I have swallowed a penny, the Daily Record reports.She then became unable to breathe and started turning blue. Horried Mr Cole-Hamilton sprang into action, recalling skills he had learned in a first aid course more than  years ago. The Lib-Dem health spokesman inverted the youngster and slapped her back with an open palm five times until she was sick. Fortunately, although the coin didnt come up, it seemingly moved enough to open Darcys airways because she let out a gasp.   Once she was breathing again, her father then managed to call . An ambulance arrived and the little girl was raced to hospital. There, she had the coin removed under general anaesthetic. Tonight, Darcy is safe and happy, bothering her brothers and eating like a horse, according to Mr Cole-Hamilton.The MSP said on Twitter he is counting blessings.Hes now calling for schoolkids to be taught first aid after learning from other parents that they wouldnt have known what to do. So many concerned friends who’ve phoned or visited today have said that they’d never received any training like that, he tweeted. So I’m going to start working with charities and first aid groups to build awareness of how easy it is to learn basic first aid. You can be that first responder.   Mr Cole-Hamilton was heading out to meet up with his we, Gill, at an event when the heart-stopping ordeal unfolded. He recalled: “I was just handing over to the sitter at .. Darcy was sitting watching YouTube in her jammies when I heard this awful strangulated scream. She said ‘I have swallowed a penny’. Then she was unable to breathe and started to change colour. “I learned first aid about  years ago when I was learning to scuba e . I knew I had to invert her and give her five or six firm backslaps and luckily after that she was sick. She didn’t sick up the coin but it must have moved it because I heard her gasp. Once I got her stabilised and breathing I called . He added: “I was just laser beam focussed. Nothing  mattered.   “She was sick and retching trying to clear the blockage. The ambulance guy saidI hadn’t done what I did the outcome would have been very dferent.” The dad-of-threes voice trembled with emotion as he spoke. He told the Record: “I remembered from  years ago the ABC rule - I managed to clear the airway, I’m just glad I didn’t need to breathe for her. “Darcy was blue lighted to the sick kids hospital. She was really brave. They took an X-ray and she was in theatre in  minutes.” The MSP was full of praise for the “heroes” of the medical profession who cared for his daughter after she swallowed the coin. He said he spent the night at the youngsters bedside.   And by this morning, she was “perky and wolfed down two bowls of Rice Krispies” for breakfast. The little girl was later discharged home, where her loved ones were said to be making a huge fuss of her. Mr Cole-Hamilton said: “Her two big brothers, Kit, who’s seven, and Finn, who’s , adore her. They are so protective of her” He added: “The outcome of this was very good but there will be other families in Scotland this year not as lucky as we were. “There are interventions you can doa child is choking and there are things we can do to prevent it, like cutting up grapes and not allowing access to marbles but houses are full of knick-knacks kids will put in their mouths. “I would like all children to be taught first aid in schools and will be reaching out to charities to see how we can do this.”

title: head teacher defends ban pupils
story: NewsHead teacher defends ban on pupils being given sweets on their BIRTHDAYSAmerican Chasey Crawford-Usher wasnt allowed sweets growing up and is alarmed by how much sugar British kids eatShareCommentsByHelena Kelly:,  MAR NewsOne Kent school is saying no to sugary sweet "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA head teacher insists she is not the fun police - despite banning children from bringing in sweets on their birthday.Chasey Crawford-Usher has also prohibited crisps and fruit juice from her school in Kent.The American-born teacher says she imposed the ban after being shocked by how much sugar British children were consuming. The self-confessed health fanatic insists the move is in the best interests of pupils.   She said: First of all, Im not the head teacher of all evil and saying no. Ive banned birthday sweets because they were becoming a huge problem in the school and mean the children were consuming processed sugar almost every day. Mrs Crawford-Usher, from New England, America, admits she wasnt allowed sweets growing up and claims her mother was a Whole Foods mum before it was trendy. She noted that children are provided with healthy and wholesome school dinners such as spaghetti bolognese, shepherds pie and roast dinners - all made with fresh ingredients.The strict head of Wateringbury Primary School also said desserts were on the table but they too were natural and unprocessed.  Despite the drastic measures, Mrs Crawford-Usher claimed students and parents have seldom complained. She said: People are angry about it for about a week and then it just becomes normal. I really havent had much of a backlash. Children can eat and drink whatever they want when they get home, I just want to provide them with healthier choices at school. The dental problems among schoolchildren now are awful and I want to do what I can to prevent it.   Its a terribly traumatic ordeal for a child to have their tooth extracted and its something I want to avoid. It comes after recent figures revealed ,  under-s needed tooth extractions last year. Public Health England estimated that youngsters were eating around eight more cubes of sugar per day than the recommended guidelines.However, Mrs Crawford-Ushers decision has come under fire on social media from Olympic race walker Tom Bosworth.He said: Again, common sense needs to be used here. Really what is happening to society to ban kids from having sweets on their birthday. - ban them every other dayyou like, but let a child be a child on their birthday though. The head hit back and said the Olympian had perhaps missed the point. She said: Yes, I think pupils should be able to eat sweets on their birthday buteach and every child brings them in to celebrate, the children would be eating them nearly every day. Also it puts an unfair pressure on parents to bring in sweets when perhaps they dont agree with them. Wateringbury CE Primary School is based near Maidstone, Kent.   Its mission statement reads: Our vision...to be an excellent primary school at the heart of the community where we inspire, excite and enable children to achieve. It was rated good in a  Ofsted report and Mrs Crawford-Usher said the obesity levels among pupils falls slightly below the national average. She has been head teacher of the school for eight years. And its not the first time the head teacher has cracked down on junk food.Last January Mrs Crawford-Usher banned the schools kids from eating crisps four days a week.  The school had previously banned sugary drinks like fizzy sodas and fruit juices too. Teachers are also encouraged to take pupils out of the classroom three times a week for a ten-minute run.Her drastic moves came after figures showed nearly one-in-five Year  pupils locally were classed as obese, with some areas of Kent leading the tables for older overweight primary school children.

title: i left unable speak after
story: NewsI was left unable to speak after massive migraine - until a musical miracleYoung teacher Amelia-Rose Hamilton was struck down by the devastating headache on her way back from parents evening and feared shed never speak properly againShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video singer-lost-voice-after-migraine-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTeacher Amelia-Rose Hamilton was making her way home from a busy day in the classroom and a parents evening when she fell seriously ill behind the wheel. The -year-old was terrfied when her face started to drop and immediately pulled over to call her mum. But she couldnt even manage to get the words out to tell her mum where she was stranded. Initially fearing she had suffered a stroke, Amelia-Rose was temporarily paralysed and unable to speak a single word. She said: I had left work at pm after parents evening and I got three minutes down the road when I suddenly felt like I didnt know who I was.   I had a blinding headache and the left side of my body quickly became limp. My immediate thought was oh my God, Im having a stroke so I pulled over and called my mum. When she asked where I was, I didnt recognise anything.Her mum called  and the ambulance rushed her to hospital , where she spent nine days in recovery. But when her music professor, Professor Grenville Hancox, arrived with his guitar and encouraged her to sing she was able to perform a faultless rendition of Yesterday, by The Beatles , despite still not being able to speak properly. Amelia-Rose, from Staplehurst in Kent, had suffered a hemiplegic migraine and throgh singing has now managed to regain her voice and speak again.She said: It was absolutely amazing, its incredible really. I went from not being able to get a single word out to singing without any stuttering at all.   It felt like my brain fog had evaporated - the dficulty and confusion was melting away. The scholar was Amelia-Roses music professor at Canterbury Christ Church University and the pair remained in contact after she graduated, running singing groups across the UK. She said: Grenville had just come from choir and had his guitar so we decided to put it to the test. Singing comes from a dferent part of the brain to speech so we knew that was something I was going to be able to do - but we didnt realise it would be to that extent so quickly.Prof Hancox filmed the moment Amelia-Rose broke her silence and burst into song at the hospital and the remarkable clip has received almost , Facebook hits.She was discharged from hospital on February  but has only been able to have a proper conversation since last week.  Following the ordeal, Amelia-Rose called the professor but was still struggling to speak - so he suggested again that she try singing instead. She said: I phoned Grenville after what had happened. He said I dont know what you are saying, sing it to me and so we spent  minutes singing down the phone to one another and his we even joined in in the background. Amelia-Rose suffers from Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, which affects the tissues in her body, and believes a recent flare in her condition caused stress, which triggered the migraines and loss of speech. She is still recovering at home and continues to have migraines but said she is singing every day to help regain her speech. Amelia-Rose said: Ive had another three migraines since and when they kick in, I cant talk and I cant move. It is only two days since I have been talking like this but I have made sure I am singing every day to keep that going. Prof Hancox helped Amelia-Rose at university, where she was a mute due to anxiety caused by childhood trauma. Over a two-year period, the music professor helped her to regain her confidence and her speech by singing. Her recent migraine is the first time in more than five years she has struggled with her speech. She said: Previously, my loss of speech was caused by my mental health but this time it was caused by a physical chemical reaction in the brain.

story: NewsMeghan Markle wears Victoria Beckham dress for second event as Kate stuns in redThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex were pictured beaming, hand in hand, as they arrived at Westminster Abbey this afternoon for a Commonwealth Day serviceShareCommentsByBradley JollySophie Evans:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video queen-meghan-kate-arrive-commonwealth-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHeavily-pregnant Meghan Markle and husband Prince Harry have arrived at Westminster Abbey for the Commonwealth Day service. The couple were the first royals to arrive, having previously been at another royal engagement earlier today. They were snapped beaming, walking hand-in-hand into the abbey. Meghan, , had changed out of her earlier outfit - a custom green wool embellished coat and matching dress - into a Victoria Beckham dress.She matched it with a chic hat and green suede heels. Duke and Duchess of Cambridge arrived at Westminster Abbey moments later for the Commonwealth event, to celebrate its  countries and . billion people. Meghan and Kate kissed each other on both cheeks and their brothers-in-law, just as the Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall arrived. Kate, , was pictured in a knee- button down coat, beige heels and a Gina Foster pillbox hat.   Meghans Victoria Beckham outfit, a chic cream number, is believed to retail at more than pound,. The dress features prints of locked chains. The Queen has also arrived at the service. She complimented her purple outfit with a silver jeweled broach. In other pictures, Prime Minister Theresa May could be seen arriving at the abbey, wearing a feathered hat and a brightly coloured necklace.  She smiled and held on to her hat as she walked towards the abbey.The Queen today praised how the Commonwealth inspires its member states to find ways of protecting the planet and it citizens.In a written message, the monarch said: In April last year, I welcomed the leaders of our  nations to Buckingham Palace and Windsor Castle for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, and we all witnessed how the Commonwealth vision offers hope, and inspires us to find ways of protecting our planet, and our people. We are able to look to the future with greater confidence and optimism as a result of the links that we share, and thanks to the networks of co-operation and mutual support to which we contribute, and on which we draw.   With enduring commitment through times of great change, successive generations have demonstrated that whilst the goodwill for which the Commonwealth is renowned may be intangible, its impact is very real. Earlier today, Meghan and Harry had visited Canadas High Commission in London, where they got an insight into Canadian culture. In a stark contrast, Meghan wore a custom green wool embellished coat and matching dress by Canadian and Turkish fashion designer Erdem for this .  She teamed it with towering black Aquazzura Deneuve bow heels, which she has worn on a number of occasions and cost around pound, a pound, black satin Givenchy clutch, and yellow gold and opal earrings. The couple watched youngsters, whose parents work at the commission, making and eating Canadas quintessential sugary treat - maple taffy. Maple syrup was poured on to crushed ice and, as it hardened, the children rolled it onto a stick and quickly devoured the delicacy traditionally served at this time of year from sugar shacks in the woods.   After watching the youngsters and listening as Harry asked how many of these are you allowed , the Duchess tried making one for herself. She then gave it to nine-year-old Elodie-Rose Dugua-Inegbese. The schoolgirl said about being given Meghans taffy: I was so excited. She said does anyone want one  And she said to me would you like it  Thenhanded it to me. It was really fun meeting Meghan and shes really pretty and was really friendly. The Duchess has an affinity with Canada, having spent seven years working in the country, mostly based in Toronto, when filming the hit series Suits.   Harry and Meghan were invited to Canada House to meet the cream of Canadian talent in the UK, from tech entrepreneurs and artists to business people and fashion designers. Canadas High Commissioner to the UK Janice Charette said: We kind of claim them a little bit as Canadians for two reasons one of course because of the duchess long timeshes worked in Canada both in Toronto and Vancouver. But as well, one of their first outings as a couple was actually at the Invictus Games in Toronto so we like to think of them as having come home here to Canada House. She added that it was signicant hosting the royal visit in the th anniversary year of the formation of the modern Commonwealth.   The high commissioner said: For me, the chance to have them here and focus on Canadian youth, withthe youth ambassador of the Commonwealth and the duchess, who has responsibilities with the Commonwealth Trust most newly, this is about the future of the Commonwealth, talking to the young people. Before leaving, the couple were given clothes for their baby. Meghan said Oh Hudsons Bay goodies when the gt box was opened and she recognised a tiny striped hat and mittens. Harry, meanwhile, made a crowd of high commission staff laugh when he picked up a tiny pair of Manitobah Mukluks - moccasins - and snfed them to seethey were real leather.The final present was an organic cotton Canadian maple leaf decorated baby bodysuit.

title: sainsburys slammed after refusing sell
story: NewsSainsbury’s slammed after refusing to sell cigarettes to -year-old womanSusan Morgan from Devon claims she was left feeling like a criminal after being refused the saleShareCommentsByAnita MerrittSofia Petkar:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsThe incident took place at the Paignton branch of Sainsburys"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old woman was left red-faced and “feeling like a criminal” after being refused cigarettes at a Sainsbury’s checkout. Susan Morgan claims she was denied the purchase at the supermarket’s Paignton branch in Devon after admitting the cigarettes were for a -year-old friend. Speaking to Devon Live , Susan said: “She is a good friend so I decided to buy her some flowers and a small bottle of vodka which I paid for and then I went to the kiosk to buy her some cigarettes. “I don’t buy myself cigarettes so I wasn’t exactly sure what to ask for and said they were for a friend.  “I was then told I couldn’t have them, even when I said how old my friend was because I was told I couldn’t prove it. “I know they have to do their job but I felt like they had made a judgement on my character immediately.” Describing the experience, Susan added: “It was so devastating because I felt insulted, embarrassed and like a criminal. “I rarely go out because I suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder and it made me feel terrible afterwards. I wont go back in that store again.”   Slamming the supermarket’s ‘Think ’ policy, Susan said: “Another time in my le I might have laughed it off, but it made me realise what a politically correct ridiculous world we live in. “At the kiosk is a sign saying you should not buy cigarettes or alcohol for anyone who is under . “There should also be a sign saying you should not buy it as a gt as you can’t prove who it is for. The -year-old remains adamant that she was singled out, and has called for everyone to be treated the same. She said: “If they want to be that strict everyone should have to sign a disclaimer saying they are not buying cigarettes or alcohol for anyone the store is that worried about getting into trouble. “I understand that they don’t know who I am buying them for but what I don’t understand is how they can fire their policy off at one customer but allow customers at the checkouts to buy alcohol with a gt bag which shows they are clearly buying it for a friend  “You can’t have it both ways you can’t just attack one lady.“ A Sainsbury’s spokesperson said: We’ve apologised to Susan for her experience and explained our Think  policy is designed to ensure that age-related products are sold safely and legally. “This includesa colleague has any reason to believe a person is attempting to buy an age-restricted product on behalf of someone under the age of . “We appreciate we may not have got it right on this occasion, but it is important our colleagues do not risk cigarettes being purchased for anyone underage.” Challenge  and Challenge  are part of a UK-wide scheme, introduced by the British Beer and Pub Association , that aim to prevent young people gaining access to age restricted products like cigarettes and alcohol. The scheme also applies to anyone purchasing age-restricted products for other people.

The mum admits that the wedding has become an obsession to her, but she is open to compromise when she finally meets the right man - though shes adamant the first dance song is not up for negotiation.  Theresa is also aware that some men may be put off by her grand plans, but shes hopeful that it wont put too many people off.Speaking on ITVs This Morning, she said: I can understand people are kinda gonna go oh God no, thats just too much too soon and I completely understand that.But Im not looking to marry someone within like the first six weeks of meeting them, like obviously you have to see how the relationship goes.While talking to Holly Willoughby, the mum also revealed her dream man would be a cheeky chap like Olly Murs, and she got a shock when he appeared on screen with a special message for her.Hi Theresa, its Olly here, Ive been hearing about your wedding day and its all planned and ready to go, he said. He continued: Im single, I hear that youre looking for the ideal man, youve said its me... right  He looked off screen and asked: Are we available that day  When the person said no, he replied that it was a shame.

title: how mafia boss snake who
story: NewsHow Mafia boss The Snake who once caught bullet with his teeth rose to powerCarmine Persico, , died in jail during a -year sentence this week for executing up to  people in a bloody war between New Yorks five crime familiesShareCommentsByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsThe mobster died during a -year prison sentence "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHe started his le of crime extorting lunch money from classmates and ended up the most feared of the old-school mafia godfathers. Along the way, Carmine “The Snake” Persico is suspected of killing  people and ordering hits on hundreds more, while surviving attempts on his own le – in one legendary incident by catching a bullet in his teeth.Now The Snake is sleeping with the fishes after dying in jail, aged , on Thursday.He grew up in the golden age of New York’s La Cosa Nostra, its five notorious crime families battling for supremacy. Persico wanted a slice of the action, dismissing his ft in stature and using his razor- sharp intelligence to rise to kingpin of the Colombo family, becoming known as “The Snake” as he double-crossed rival families to slither to power. And even after his luck ran out, and he was jailed for  years in , he continued to rule from behind bars, taking out contracts on those who dared to mess with the master.   He never broke the mafia’s Omertagrave, code of silence, and was “an old-school tough guy”, according to Frank Dimatteo, who grew up in the mob and co-wrote biography Carmine the Snake: Carmine Persico and His Murderous Mafia Family. Dimatteo says: “He’s a throwback to the real gangsters, not like these make-believe gangsters. You gotta give him respect for it.” Carmine John Persico Jr was born in Red Hook, Brooklyn, on August , . His father worked as a legal stenographer, but Persico idolised mobsters. As a kid, he was demanding his peers’ lunch money, as a teenager he formed the Garfield Boys gang. At , he was charged with killing a rival gang member, but the charge was dropped. By , he had been arrested for murder a second time.   He caught the eye of Frankie Abbatemarco, a member of the Profaci crime family – later to become the Colombo family – who hired him as an enforcer. He was in. But how to rise through the ranks  On October , , he was involved in one of the decade’s most famous mafia hits, the killing of crime boss Albert Anastasia, gunned down by the so-called “barbershop quartet” while getting a shave in the Park Sheraton hotel in Manhattan. No one was ever charged, but it’s believed Persico acted alongside one of the Gallo brothers, Crazy Joey. Later, when he learned kingpin Joe Profaci was creaming more cash than he should from his foot soldiers, Persico plotted with Gallo brothers, Joey, Albert and Larry, to take him out. Profaci caught wind of it, and bribed Persico to turn on the Gallos. On Profaci’s orders, Persico lured Larry Gallo to the Sahara Lounge in Brooklyn, and very nearly strangled him.   Luckily, for Gallo, a policeman walked in. Charges against Persico were dropped when Gallo refused to give evidence. The double-cross earned Persico his nickname The Snake, which he did not like. The Gallos tried to assassinate Persico, shooting him in the face. One of the bullets lodged in his mouth, but legend has it Persico spat it out and drove off. A few years later, he took revenge, killing Joe Gallo. When Profaci died of cancer, Joe Colombo replaced him, making Persico a “capo” in . Ten years later, Persico got to the top of the tree after Colombo was shot and paralysed. Michael Benson, who co-wrote The Snake’s biography with Dimatteo, says: “Carmine wanted to do just one thing with his le: be the leader of the gang, Top Cat. He acquired power the way other men breathe.”  Persico was in and out of jail throughout his tenure, but ran his operation from inside, making huge profits from loan sharking and racketeering. FBI wiretaps finally caught up with him and all five mafia families, resulting in the Mafia Commission Trial in the s. The Snake defended himself, and one judge said he was “one of the most intelligent people I have ever seen in my le”. He lost anyway and in  was put away for good for extorting millions. Seven others went down with him. An infection in his leg – for which he resisted amputation – and diabetes, ultimately led to Persico’s death at a federal jail in Butner, North Carolina. He leaves a we, two children, and  grandchildren. The Snake’s second nickname was “Immortal”, but, thankfully, it is only the legend that lives on.

title: spaghetti bolognese isnt real its
story: NewsSpaghetti Bolognese isnt real its fake news, says Mayor of BolognaThe Mayor of Bologna in Italy has had enough of people sharing their love for Spaghetti Bolognese which he says is a fake dishShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  MAR NewsSpaghetti bolognese is not real, says Mayor of Bologna "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email If you look at the menus of most Italian restaurants in the UK, youre bound to find Spaghetti Bolognese listed among the items on offer.Youll also find jars of bolognese sauce for sale in the aisles of your local supermarkets, be it a Tesco, a Waitrose or an Aldi. But it turns out theres really no such thing as Spaghetti Bolognese, at least according to Virginio Merola, the Mayor of Bologna, a city in Itays Emilia-Romagna region. He claims the the popular pasta dish is fake news and he wants everyone to know it.  The -year-old recently shared a hilarious post on Twitter announcing he was collecting photos of Spaghetti Bolognese from around the world.He wrote: Dear citizens, Im collecting photos of Spaghetti Bolognese around the world, speaking of fake news. Virginio then shared a snap of a specials board from a London restaurant, selling the dish for pound. and asked people to send in their own photos.He plans to use these photos to create an exhibit for the citys new FICO Eataly World, which is the largest food theme park in the world.  People on social media were quick to reply to Virginio sharing their own hilarious photos - including a packet of Knorr bolognese sauce mix from Austria, a look at a British school dinner menu and a black board offering Bolonske Spagety in Moravia. Many people believe that Bolognese originated in Bologna, but as the Mayor reveals, this is simply not the case.Speaking to Italian radio broadcaster RAI, he said: Spaghetti Bolognese doesnt actually exist, yet its famous the world over.What wed prefer the world to know is that Bologna invented tagliatelle, tortellini and lasagne.  Additionally he told the : It is strange to be famous all over the world for a dish that isnt ours.Of course we are happy that it draws attention to our city, but we would prefer to be known for the quality food that is part of our culinary tradition. In Italy, the dish we commonly call Bolognese, is actually referred to as a Ragugrave sauce, which features much less meat and is spread throughout the pasta, instead of being spooned over the top. It is also typically served with a sturdier type of pasta, such as tagliatelle instead of spaghetti.

title: woman makes hilariously salty survey
story: NewsWoman hilariously gets her own back on housemates who never put the bin outA student from the University of Lancaster has shared the passive aggressive survey she was recently sent by her housemateShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsTheres no such thing as magical bin pixies says Ruth Came"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLiving with a group of people can be dficult sometimes, especiallyyou dont know each other all that well.Youll find some people in the house will do their fair share of the chores, while others will sit back and ignore the mountain of washing up and never nip to Tesco to buy more milk. story: NewsBoeing  MAX  grounded - what happened in first fatal crash involving same aircraftSeven British passengers and one from Ireland were among  people in the Ethiopian Airlines tragedy but a Lion Air plane had crashed just five months beforeShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  MAR NewsAll  people on board the Ethiopian Airlines flight were killed "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Six minutes after take off yesterday Ethiopian Airlines  MAX  bound for Nairobi crashed , killing all  people on board.Seven British passengers and one from Ireland were among those killed when the aircraft went down after taking off from Addis Ababa on its way to Nairobi. Among those to lose their lives in the tragedy were UN worker, Joanna Toole, , from Exmouth, Devon, Irishman Michael Mick Ryan, a dad of two who worked for the UNs World Food Programme , Joseph Waithaka - a dual Kenyan and British national and polar tourism expert Sarah Auffret.But this the second time in less than six months a Boeing  MAX has crashed with devastating results.Lion Air Flight  crashed into the sea just  minutes after take-off from Jakarta in Indonesia while on its way to Pangkal Pinang on October  last year.   All  passengers and crew were killed. Crew on the Ethiopian Airlines plane lost contact with air traffic control just after take-off, at around :am yesterday. Ethiopian Airlines CEO, Tewolde GebreMariam, revealed the polit had reported he was experiencing technical dficulties just after take-off and had requested permission toto the airport. This was granted - but just minutes later the plane plummeted to earth, killing all on board. Eyewitnesses have said they saw smoke coming from the plane but GebreMariam insists a pre-flight check didnt reveal any issues.   The pilot had more than , hours flying experience and an excellent flying record. At a press conference, GebreMariam said: As it is a fresh incident, we have not been able to determine the cause. An investigation has now been launched into the aviation tragedy and several airlines have already grounded their Boeing  Max s. Ethiopia along with carriers in China and the Cayman Islands has suspended flying Boeing  MAX s as an extra safety precaution. Ethiopian Airlines, Africas biggest commercial carrier, said: Although we dont yet know the cause of the accident, we have to decide to ground the particular fleet as an extra safety precaution.   China has made the same decision in viewthe fact that the two air crashes were newly delivered Boeing - aircraft. Cayman Airlines has also grounded the planes while the investigation is carried out. At the moment there is no evidence of a link between the two crashes but there are similarities, which is believed to have prompted fears in airlines around the world.And one aviation analyst, Mary Schiavo, told CNN both incidents were highly suspicious.She added: Here we have a brand-new aircraft thats gone down twice in a year.   That rings alarm bells in the aviation industry, because that doesnt just happen. Both planes crashed just minutes into their journeys and neither had reported technical faults. The Boeing  is the companys biggest selling aircraft. It is described as a workhorse for short and medium haul flights and the  max is the newest model. Airlines have already ordered thousands of them. Each month Boeing makes  new s every month.   In a statement on the Ethiopian crash: Boeing is deeply saddened to learn of the passing of the passengers and crew on Ethiopian Airlines Flight , a  MAX  airplane. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the families and loved ones of the passengers and crew on board and stand ready to support the Ethiopian Airlines team. A Boeing technical team will be travelling to the crash site to provide technical assistance under the direction of the Ethiopia Accident Investigation Bureau and U.S. National Transportation Safety Board. As investigators start the second day on examining exactly what caused the Ethiopian Airlines plane to plummet from the sky, what happened to Lion Air Flight . The probe into what downed the jet last October is still on going but a preliminary investigation revealed both passengers and crew on its previous flight had reported problems.  It has also been reported there were signs of instrument failure on previous flights. Following the fatal crash in October, Boeing warned all airlines using the  MAX to avoid ing abruptly. As with the Ethiopian Airlines crash, crew on board the Lion Air plane had also asked for permission toto the airport. But then, abruptly, contact between the aircraft and air traffic control was lost. The doomed plane went into the ocean close to a oil rig and crew reported that the jet ed into the water with its nose down.  Initial investigations after the Lion Air crash seem to suggest it could have been caused by faulty data, which led the crew to believe the nose was tilted at a higher angle than it was in reality. The new  max s had been fitted with a new safety system which is designed to automatically pull the nose of the plane downdata on board suggests it is not at the correct angle, The prelim report also highlighted six other identied problems, which had occurred since October . Just the day before the planes fatal crash, the s angle-of-attack sensor had been replaced after it encountered problems. This measures the angle between the wings and the flow of air around the plane.  And chillingly in the flight before the doomed take-off to pilot had issued a Pan Pan call. The aircraft was travelling between Denpasar on Bali to Jakarta and the Pan Pan alert is one less serious than Mayday. Abormal conditions becayse of instrument failure were blamed but the crew managed to land the aircraft safely. A warning device, known as the stick shaker, which alerts flight crew as tothe aircraft is about to stall was active throughout the final flight before the crash. The preliminary report says the flight should not have continuedthe stick shaker was active because it was an un-airworthy condition.  And even during Flight JT, the system was active, possibly due to a faulty sensor. This could have forced the planes nose down, even when it wasnt stalling. In the minutes after take-off, the flight also failed to gain normal height. It should have reached , feet but remained at around , feet. The speed, which should have risen steadily, was also erratic. Damage to the aircraft was said to have been caused by a high energy impact although the cockpit voice recorder has not yet been recovered, which could provide more detailed information as to what happened. A full investigation report into what happened to Lion Air Flight  is expected later this year.

title: hindu man who mistakenly ate
story: NewsHindu man who mistakenly ate beef wants supermarket to pay for cleansing tripJaswinder Paul says his family havent talked to him since he ate a chunk of beef that he thought was lamb, and he needs to go home to India to be "puried" by priestsShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsHe bought the meat from a Countdown store in New Zealand "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Hindu man who claims he mistakenly ate beef labelled as lamb wants a supermarket to pay for a trip to India so he can take part in a cleansing ritual. Jaswinder Paul claims he bought a chunk of meat labelled lamb roast and was horried after discovering that it was actually beef. The barber didnt find out until after he had cooked it and eaten it - and he claims his family hasnt talked to him since. Mr Paul, from Blenheim, New Zealand, is now demanding the Countdown supermarket pay for a trip to his native India so he can be puried by priests after he broke his religious vow. Hindus consider the cow to be a sacred symbol of le. Mr Paul, who runs his own barber shop, told Stuff.co.nz: According to my religion, I have to go back to my country and do sacred things for four to six weeks, and be puried by priests, so I can continue on my religious path. Its a long process. Travelling to Delhi, he said, would require him to close his shop and pay thousands for flights, accommodation and food. Mr Paul said he complained to the supermarket and was offered a voucher as a goodwill gesture.   But he refused and asked the company to pay for his trip instead. That hasnt happened and he is not considering legal action as a last resort. He said: I understand this looks like a simple matter, but for me this is very hard. I break my religion [vows] because of someone s negligence. I know my society back from my home will not accept me with this breach of the religions conditions. It appears Mr Paul wont get his way. A spokeswoman for Countdown told Stuff.co.nz that an in-store labelling error resulted in a pack of beef mince being sold with both beef and lamb labels. She said the supermarket was sorry for the mistake and respects Mr Pauls beliefs, and that the goodwill gesture still stands.

title: unforgettable moment premature baby twins
story: NewsMums tears of joy as premature baby twins embrace as theyre finally reunitedZoe and Olivia were born at  weeks and had to spend a month apartShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsIts been a really emotionally-charged time for the new parents "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tiny twins Zoe and Olivia spent  weeks together inside the womb before making their debut into the world.Having never been apart, however, it was at this point they were separated for the first time for a month to prevent one twin from accidentally suffocating the other. It took  days for doctors to be satisfied that the twins were strong enough to be reunited, and the emotionally-charged moment was made all the more poignant when Zoe reached out to hug her older sister. The decision to deliver the girls early was made after doctors were concerned that one of them was in distress.Mum Ann Les pregnancy had been a high-risk one, with her precious girls sharing an amniotic sac.Known as monochorionic monoamniotc twins, this sort of multiple pregnancy means there is only  per cent chance the twins will survive past  weeks.   Throughout her pregnancy from  week mark, Ann, from Melbourne, Australia, had had to have fortnightly ultrasound scans to monitor the girls development.On the day of their delivery, Olivia came first - with a loud cry, Ann tells Daily Mail Australia .Zoe came next but was breech, so after a bit of pulling, the doctor managed to get her out. She didnt cry or move which made us really concerned.  Both girls were quickly taken by the midwives to the paediatric team for assessment. Fast forward a month and Ann was finally able to have a much anticipated twin cuddle. We waited  days exactly for our first twin cuddle and it was so much more than we could have expected, she adds. Olivia was placed on me first, then when it was Zoes turn she reached out her left arm and hugged her sister. My tears were flowing, its a moment Ill never forget. The proud mum shared the beautul moment on Instagram .Now Ann is hopeful that she can take her girls home with her by mid-April. It has been emotionally draining for my husband and I, but now that they have passed the one month mark, their chances of survival are now greater than  per cent, she said.

title: double boost for dundee united as butcher and sow set to return
story: Dundee United are to receive a double boost for today’s Championship trip to take on struggling Partick Thistle.Midfielder Calum Butcher s from his one-game cup suspension, served last Sunday, while striker Osman Sow is in line to get a place on the bench after injury.Butcher’sshould add some steel to the Tangerines engine-room as they look to get the better of the bottom-placed Jags in Glasgow and, hopefully, close the gap on league leaders Ross County.Swedish hitman Sow has recovered from a calf problem and may be risked at some point this afternoon as United look to find the back of the net from open play after a deluge of penalty-kick goals in recent weeks.Terrors manager Robbie Neilson was delighted to have some key men back and available to choose from.“Butcher’s back in, which is great,” he said.“He brings that experience and that physicality so I’m pleased to bring him in.“Sow is fit. He has trained and will be involved today.“He had a wee calf problem which tightened up last Thursday.“We tried him on the Friday and he just didn’t think it was right, so we felt that it was better just to leave him out of it as opposed to putting him on the bench – bringing him on for  minutes and it blows up after .“I just felt last Sunday wasn’t the right one to put him in but he’ll be available today.“He’s a top player. I knew when I got him that it was going to take a bit of time to build him up and slowly get him where he is but he’s here for a period and there’s no doubt he’s got ability.“It’s just getting him on the pitch and getting him as fit as we can as quickly as we can without injuring him.”And Robbie hopes the -year-old’scan spur United on in the final third in their quest to come away from Maryhill with all three points.Expressing his disappointment about the lack of goals scored lately, he said: “We’ve not scored as many as we would like but when you look at the previous game at home, in the first  minutes, we had four or five chances to put the ball in the net and we didn’t do it.“It will come, we’re creating chances and just maybe not taking them but the most important thing is that you create.”

title: dundee need to pick up points at home says jim mcintyre
story: Home matches against Hearts are where Dundee need to be picking up points, according to manager Jim McIntyre.The Dens boss felt his side were worth at least a point from Saturday’s - defeat to the Jambos but he concedes “it’s about making sure you are good in both boxes and we weren’t”.There were positives in the performance for the Dark Blues boss as his side created decent opportunities but conceded a poor th-minute winner from Sean Clare.Jim said: “It’s hard to be critical because it’s so scrappy.“It’s not asthey’ve cut us open.“Where I’m disappointed is that we don’t stop the cross but we have men in place and it is an old-fashioned stramash where the ball is stuck between bodies.“They got a toe-poke to it and it was a really frustrating goal, a scrappy, poor goal to give away.”Asked about the chances in the opening minutes of the game, Jim replied: “They are the opportunities you have to take.“Goals give you a real surge in belief but we are showing plenty of spirit because we are conceding the first goal a lot but we are coming back and still at it in the th minute.“At the same time, we are at home and we need to be picking up points against Hearts at Dens.“We had a brilliant result against them at Tynecastle but we want to be picking them up here and I felt there was enough in the performance to deserve at least a point.“It’s about making sure you are good in both boxes and we weren’t.”

title: Bags of help at North Kessock beach clean
story: A MAJOR Black Isle beach clean against the backdrop of one of the peninsularsquos most recognisable landmarks recovered  bags of waste, among it syringes, plastic and fishing lines.It is the fth time a group led by Greenpeace volunteers from Inverness has cleaned the beach at Scarabs at North Kessock near the Kessock Bridge.Greenpeace activists ldquoadopted the beach via the Marine Conservation Society with the idea of not only cleaning up on a regular basis, but also monitoring results over a longer period.David Smith, of Greenpeace Inverness, said: ldquoWe had a great turn-out which I think was due to online shares, it was really good to have so many people along.The community beach clean attracted around  volunteers, among them Highland Green MSP John Finnie.Mr Finnie said: ldquoIt was a very successful day. It seemed to be very well attended which was great as it felt like we were all part of a community effort.Mr Finnie went on to say that although these litter clean-ups were essential, the long-term goal should be to stop littering altogether: ldquoIdeally we want a situation where people are not dropping any litter. Prevention is better than cure.Among the litter picked up from the popular recreational area were six used syringes which Mr Smith believes were washed up rather than dumped there.A spokesman for Highland Council said: ldquoMost pharmacies offer a free needle disposal service. Failing that, people can put them in a safe container and take them to out to the waste management team at Lotland Street. Discarded needles should not be taken to recycling centres as they are classed as special waste.Greenpeace Inverness was established in October  and has supported the organisationrsquos national and global campaigns.Monday  Mar  : PM

title: High Life Highland boss retires
story: The chief executive of High Le Highland , the biggest leisure services provider in the region, has announced his intention to retire from the top job in the summer.Ian Murray has been the boss of the charity since it was created by Highland Council in October  when it was tasked with delivering and developing the local authorityrsquos culture, learning, sport, leisure and health and well-being services.Since then it has grown to employ more than  full and part-time staff and support more than  volunteers with an annual turnover of pound million.Mr Murray first moved to the Highlands  years ago to take up the position of depute director of leisure services with what was then Ross and Cromarty District Council.When Highland Council was formed in  he moved to the region-wide remit of head of community learning and leisure before leading the transition of those services to High Le Highland seven years ago.Mr Murray said: ldquoLeading the transition to High Le Highland and the seven years since has been the most challenging, rewarding and enjoyable period in my career.ldquoSince HLH began, visitor numbers have grown almost three fold, annual income has doubled, reliance on council funding reduced by half and HLH has been asked by the council and several community groups to adopt  additional services, from the formerly community-run pools in Bettyhill and Poolewe to more recently the councilrsquos school music tutor service.ldquoI have been very fortunate to have been supported throughout by a very motivated, professional and innovative team across everything we do.HLH was recently the centre of tensions over funding as Highland Council drew up its budget and sought to make cuts that saw the price of HLH membership rise by around pound. In draft budget papers, a move to increase the revenue target by pound. million was tabled but later removed.Monday  Mar  : PM

title: Inverness Music Festival ends on a high
story: MUSIC lovers enjoyed a host of outstanding performances at the latest outing for an event showcasing young Highland talent.This yearrsquos Inverness Music Festival concluded on Wednesday with the grand finale Premier Competition.Chairwoman Jean Slater said the musical skill on show this year had been exceptional.ldquoWersquove had an excellent standard of talent, she said. ldquoI know the adjudicators are very pleased with the standards which are taught in Highland schools.Dozens of young musicians from across the region won prizes, including Cannich Bridge Primary School which won the
