They achieved two platinum albums and seven top ten hits, blazing a trail through the music industry of the early Noughties.She was all set to become a PE teacher, however, before Mis-Teeq came along.ldquoI had such affection for performing at school ndash I always felt like I was my best self when I was up on stage in the plays, or singing or dancing, she says.ldquoAnd yet, in my pragmatic head, I thought it couldnrsquot possibly be my career, so I set myself what I thought were more realistic goals.ldquoI knew and understood the path to becoming a PE teacher ndash I had no idea what path you took to become a singer. I didnrsquot want to be some airy fairy person, running around wanting to be a pop star.ldquoI was on my way to Loughborough University when I met a woman who had her own production company, who was looking for developing artists and I got talking to her. Suddenly it felt like the music industry might not be on planet Mars, maybe it was something I could get into.She pauses. ldquoThat was the thing, see  I think deep down in my heart I knew I always wanted to be a singer, I just didnrsquot know how to get there, she says. ldquoI lived in a small town, I didnrsquot have any connections whatsoever with that world so it seemed like something to look on and admire from afar, but not actually be part of.ldquoAnd yet ndash at college, there was an instinct in me, a niggle that made me think I should be doing something dferent. I never ignore that niggle.She adds, laughing: ldquoTherersquos a le lesson in there ndash never ignore your gut instinct.When she looks back at the years she spent in Mis-Teeq, Dixon says it feels ldquotoo good to be true.ldquoI was in a girl band, we had hits and awards and travelled the world ndash Irsquod never been on an aeroplane before Mis-Teeq, she marvels. ldquoWe did everything. On paper it shouldnrsquot have worked. But it did and it changed my le.ldquoIt made me believe. Even now, when I look back, I think ndashthatrsquos what I achieved when I had nothing, then imagine what I can achieve now ldquoI was so happy in Mis-Teeq. I wouldnrsquot be here, writing books, judging on BGT, doing Strictly,it hadnrsquot been for the girls. I owe everything to them.Dixon admits there were times when the group considered giving up.Who are Scotlands funniest  people ldquoWe were broke, she says, simply. ldquoFor four years, we had no money. We had walked away from college courses and university places to join a girl band, and what was our plan B  Was there ever a back-up  I honestly donrsquot think so. It was ludicrous. I think we were so in the moment, so caught up in what we wanted to do, that there was just no option other than it working.ldquoBut my mum always says to me,you wake up every day and it feels right and you are happy, then trust your instinct and do it. And maybe itrsquos because we were so headstrong and focussed that we didnrsquot give up.ldquoPeople try to put you in a box or dismiss you, but what we achieved proves thatyou work hard,you are authentic, then eventhe odds are against you it doesnrsquot mean you canrsquot succeed.The group split in .ldquoThe end of Mis-Teeq felt like the end of a marriage, says Dixon. ldquoIt was amicable, a joint decision, but there was still heartache and a lot of tears.ldquoThings had come to a natural end and we decided to go our separate ways. It was a walk into the unknown ndash and then, I had the dream scenario.Dixon was offered a lucrative deal with Polydor, and she spent  months writing and recording her solo debut album, Fired Up, alongside producers like Richard X, Brian Higgins, Estelle and Paul Epworth. But her joy evaporated when in November , Dixon was dropped by the label just as her one-year-old marriage to rapper MC Harvey collapsed, following revelations he had had an affair with singer Javine Hylton.ldquoIrsquod spent  months working on my solo album, putting all my eggs in one basket and they dropped me, says Dixon. ldquoI was left fumbling in the dark. I lost everything.She adds: ldquoWhen I finally stopped feeling sorry for myself, I realised I had to come up with a new plan. I made some calls, sent some emails.One of those calls was to Charlotte Oates, celebrity producer and talent scout for Strictly Come Dancing.ldquoA lot of people were a bit snobby about reality shows, but I loved Strictly and I told Charlotte Irsquod love to do itI could, she recalls.Dixon signed up for the fth series of Strictly in , partnered with professional dancer Matthew Cutler. She quickly became the favourite and beat actor Matt Di Angelo and Flavia Cacace in the final to win the glitterball trophy.ldquoIt was lovely, she sighs. ldquoIf I ever watch the dances back, it brings up so many emotions and Irsquom in floods of tears. It felt transformational, that show. I got a lot of love and support when I won Strictly and it made me feel, actually, that things were going to be okay after all. Strictly saved me.After a spell as a judge on the dance show, Dixon switched seats to Britainrsquos Got Talent, where she currently resides alongside Simon Cowell, Amanda Holden and David Walliams. She has hosted many TV shows, including Alesharsquos Street Dance Stars on CBBC, Children in Need and ITVrsquos Dance, Dance, Dance.Her third book, Secret Supervillain vs Lightning Girl, will be published on March . It is the latest adventure of Aurora Beam, a little girl who discovers she is descended from a long line of superheroes.Dixon has written the books in collaboration with The It Girl author Katy Birchall.ldquoIrsquom really grateful to Katy and the team at Scholastic, they have really helped me bring all of my characters and ideas to le, she says.ldquoIrsquove always loved the idea of writing something. Irsquom not mad about doing an autobiography, but Irsquod thought something on wellness maybe, or a childrenrsquos book. The inspiration came from wanting my daughter to feel empowered. I wanted to create a positive role model, to say that itrsquos okay to be dferent, itrsquos okay to be me.Shaun Ryder: "If it hadnt been for music I dont think I would be here."ldquoEvery single child deserves to feel included. I want readers to see themselves in Aurora, who is dealing with troubles at home and at school alongside finding she has new superpowers.As a child, Dixon read a lot but says no one character struck a chord with her.ldquoI liked Judy Blume, because she was a bit edgy, she says. ldquoWith Are You There God, Itrsquos Me Margaret, you always kind of felt you shouldnrsquot be reading it, and I loved that.ldquoBut there was no single character I really identied with ndash none that stayed with me, that I could see myself in.She adds: ldquoI donrsquot want my daughter to feel like that. I think things are changing, slowly ndash we live in a time where anything feels possible and it is great that underdogs, people who may have once just been pushed aside or overlooked, finally have a voice.ldquoBut only one per cent of British childrenrsquos books feature a main character who is black or minority ethnic, and statistics like that show there is still a long, long way to go.Finding space and time to write can be tricky, Dixon admits.ldquoDo I hide away for hours and write and write  God no, she laughs. ldquoWith Azura about, not a chance.ldquoI write on aeroplanes, or in the car, or at night in bed when Azura is asleep. Itrsquos the same with songwriting ndash I can never do it in the house, I have to go into the studio and physically put some distance between me and everyday le. I love writing, and I hope I always do it now. But finding a quiet place in my house to do it for hours on end  Never going to happen.Away from her multiple day jobs, Dixon lends her name and time to a range of good causes. She is currently working on a documentary about animals being used for entertainment.ldquoIf you are blessed with a , you should use it wisely, she says, adding emphatically: ldquoElephant rides, tiger selfies ndash itrsquos all just wrong. I feel very passionately about animal protection. My mother educated me. She showed me things that maybe people donrsquot like to look at, because they are afraid to. Irsquom the kind of person who looks, evenit hurts, because I believe knowledge is power. If you see it, you can do something about it.ldquoI canrsquot watch distressing videos, like the ones that come up on social media, and then just go about my day as usual.ldquoI have to act. AndI can do something that makes a few people look dferently at an issue, then job done. Irsquom quite a heart-on-my-sleeve kind of person.Itrsquos why, she thinks, audiences have warmed to her as a judge on shows like Britainrsquos Got Talent, where a string of hopefuls put themselves in the firing line in a bid to become famous.ldquoI never forget itrsquos a human being standing in front of me, she says. ldquoI always try to have a connection with that person ndash this is someone who is putting themselves out there, taking a step and we are all dferent and we all have our stories and experiences.ldquoYou shouldnrsquot forget that in the heat of making a television programme.ALESHArsquoS TRIUMPHSMIS-TEEQ: As part of Mis-Teeq, alongside Sabrina Washington and Su-Elise Nash, Alesha Dixon achieved two platinum albums and seven top ten hits, a Mobo award and a Brit nomination.SOLO CAREER: Alesha is the singer and author of nine top  singles and three platinum albums. Her single, The Boy Does Nothing, is a million-seller and reached the top  in  global territories. Her album The Alesha Show was one of only five platinum-selling albums in .STRICTLY CHAMPION: In , on series five of the hit BBC ONE dance show, Alesha took the glitterball trophy with professional partner Matthew Cutler. She holds the record for the highest average score in Strictly history with . points ndash and thats despite never achieving a perfect  point score for a single routine. Alesha went on to sit on the Strictly judging  for three series from -.CHARITY AMBASSADOR: Alesha supports a range of charities including World Animal Protection and Action Aid. In  she climbed Mount Kilimanjaro with a group of other celebrities to raise more than a million pounds for Comic Relief.

title: scotlands-insider-guide-anstruther
story: Anstruther is the biggest of them, boasting an abundance of the quintessential features ndash ancient harbours, cute cottages, good beaches and fantastic fish suppers - folk come from far and wide to experience.Indeed, visitors to Anster, as it is known locally, actually get two villages for the price of one, since Cellardyke - one of less well known East Neuk names ndash all but merges with its bigger neighbour.Historic HighlightsAnstruther is thought to date back to the early th century. Split into ldquoeaster and ldquowester sides by the Dreel Burn, it was a thriving fishing port until the mid-s and supported associated industries such as tanning, boatbuilding and fish-curing.In , writer James Melville recorded a graphic account in his diary of a ship from the Spanish Armada arriving with  sailors aboard - local legend has it that many of the Spaniards stayed on due to the warmth of the local hospitality.These days tourism and culture are the main employers. Well-kent local faces include former Radio One DJ Edith Bowman and musician King Creosote, aka Kenny Anderson.Scotlands Insider Guide: BrodickWhat to doOn arrival, get your bearings with a harbourside walk from Anstruther to Cellardyke, stopping off along the way at the Scottish Fisheries Museum . Now in its th year, this wonderful museum tells the story of ldquoboats, fish and folk though an array of vessels, artworks and personal testimonies. Kids love the hands-on exhibits featuring dressing up, bunk beds and puzzles, and until June therersquos also a exhibition on Anstrutherrsquos connection to the global tea trade.Just across the way on Middle Pier is Anstruther Leboat Station, established in  at the request of local fishermen, which has two active boats, the Kingdom of Fe and the Akira. Still run by committed volunteers, it welcomes visitors.Catherine Watson has some fantastic insider recommendations for things to do in her vibrant home town.ldquoThe short but rewarding walk between Anstruther and Pittenweem takes in sandy Billow Ness beach, she says. ldquoMake sure to stop for a shot on the swings and a nose around the rock pools. You can also see the remnants of the old tidal bathing pool where my dad learned to swim .ldquoFor a cracking view over to the Anstruther skyline, take a foray into the graveyard of Anstruther Wester Church and sit on one of the benches overlooking the water. The graveyard is home to a medieval coffin and th century gravestones with fascinating memento mori symbols.ldquoIrsquove always loved the story about Princess Titaua Marama, who was Chiefess of Haapiti in French Polynesia but somehow ended up marrying a Fer and travelling thousands of miles to live out her days in Anstruther. She died in  and you can check out her pink gravestone in the grounds of St Adrianrsquos Church.ldquoKnown locally as lsquothe steppiesrsquo, the giant stepping stones over the Dreel Burn at Castle Beach can save you a bit of timeyoursquore heading to the pub or the chippy. As long as itrsquos not high tide, that is.ldquoIrsquod also highly recommend Anster Nichts, run by the wonderful Anstruther Improvements Associationoffering community talks, films and cultural events in the Dreel Halls, which are open to all.Scotlands Insider Guide: KirkwallWhere to EatNo visit to Anster would be complete without a fish supper and although the award-winning Anstruther Fish Bar on Shore Street gets most of the publicityitrsquos not the only great chippy in town. Both the Wee Chippy and Waterfront Chip Shopare also superb. Shore Street is also the place to go for ice cream.If itrsquos Machelin-starred excellence yoursquore after, The Cellar, on East Green,delivers in every way. Chef Billy Boyter, a local boy, uses the best seasonal local ingredients to produce simple but exquisite dishes, served in beautul, informal surroundings. A genuine treat at any time of year.Iain Leiper has been visiting Anstruther for  years and still highly recommends Barnettrsquos Bakery in Cellardyke. ldquoA recent visit confirmed Barnettrsquos still makes the best rhubarb pies, he says. ldquoFirst sampled in the late s!The scones at Curiositeas on Shore Street are super, while Coast Coffee in Cellardyke serves great value sandwiches, paninis and wraps, and some of the best coffee in the East Neuk.Catherine Watson speaks highly of the Dreel Tavern on High Street West. ldquoThere are a remarkable number of pubs in Anstruther for such a small population but The Dreel is the quaintest by far. Itrsquos the kind of bar you feel compelled to show off to visitors as itrsquos everything a village pub should be, complete with dinky beer garden overlooking the river and an open fireplace to keep you cosy in winter. And the food is excellent.Scotlands Insider Guide: TroonWhere to shopDos Mundoson Rodger Street, has a quirky collection of clothes, artworks and jewellery, not to mention ethical cleaning products and gt. Gibbles Gts on Shore Street is also a favourite gt shop with locals and visitors alike.Jo Macfarlanemakes her beautul vegan scented candles at her studio in Cunzie Street and also offers workshops and classes.Petrsquos Pantry, meanwhile, on High Street Easthas a massive selection of gourmet food and accessories for the special dog, cat, rabbit, guinea pig or hamster in your le.Where to stayRoom with a view: The Bankoffers spacious big rooms, open fires, lovely gardens and great views over the Firth of Forth. Rooms from pound per night.Cosy: Attention to detail is everything at Lahloo BB, located in a traditional white-painted house just a few minutesrsquo walk from the harbour. Rooms from pound a night.Cheap and cheerful: Murray Library Hostel offers top-notch accommodation and facilities for backpackers in a perfect location. Also caters for larger groups. From pound a night.What to do nearbyFrom April to September you can take a boat from Anstruther to the Isle of May, a national nature reserve home to tens of thousands of seabirds including puffins, guillemots and terns, not to mention a large population of harbour and grey seals. Therersquos also an ancient monument and lighthouse. A smashing day out.Walk  minutes northup the coast from Anstruther and yoursquoll come to the fascinating Caves of Caiplie, which were used as place of Christina worship from the th century.Medieval Kellie Castle and Gardens, a -minute drive from Anstruther, offers a fascinating insight into the lives of the artistic Lorimer family who lived there for three generations from the late th century.Over the next couple of weeks Irsquoll be going to Banchory and Helensburgh. title: corbyns-constitutional-adviser-tells-him-to-create-partnership-government-with-scotland
story: Baroness Pauline Bryan of Partick appointed by Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn last year explicitly to develop the partyrsquos constitutional policy, is recommending greater devolution of power to Scotland - by ensuring the future relationship between Holyrood and Westminster is based on an equal footing.For the first time she will today launch her initial lsquopartnership not hierarchyrsquo proposals for change to the Labour Party, which would involve creating a Chamber of the Nations and Regions to replace the House of Lords in a move that Baroness Bryan believes would mean the Scottish Parliament was no longer subordinate to Westminster.It comes as previously unreleased poll for the Electoral Reform Society by BMG shows that, when dont knows are excluded, support for an elected upper chamber sits at % for SNP voters and % for Conservatives.ERS says that suggest that Lords reform could be a vote winner for the party . A majority of all main partiesrsquo supporters backed an elected second chamber.The Bryan paper that kicks off Labours review of its constitutional policy is set to take the party much closer to backing full federalism and a new constitutional settlement for the UK "based on the commitment to redistribute power and wealth, and that takes account of the consequences of Brexit".In her analysis of future principles, she says a new federal set-up will "move from the existing model, where power is devolved from the central state to Scotland".Baroness Bryan, who is the designated lead for updating the partyrsquos policy on federalism and Lords reform says the lsquopartnershiprsquo model for Westminster and Scotland would be backed by the reformed second chamber.The peer adds: "The point is to change the relationship so that the Scottish Parliament is no longer subordinate to Westminster. A second chamber of the Regions and Nations would change the nature of the relations to shared government on the cross territorial issues."UK-wide, ldquoInstead of the House of Commons having automatic primacy, this would be a new settlement of shared sovereignty, Baroness Bryan says.She believes a reformed ndash most-likely directly elected ndash second chamber would have a key role in this, bringing the nations and regions together to agree what powers should be devolved and which should be shared.Willie Sullivan, director of ERS Scotland, said: ldquoThe piecemeal, ad hoc approach to democratic change in the UK has held us back, with a constant, low-level constitutional crisis: with Scotland and the other nations pitted against Westminster, and vice versa."That is not a sustainable relationship and it is time for an approach the puts citizens at the centre, not the needs of politicians. What form this reform takes is up for discussion, but it is good to see parties considering this in the round.ldquoAs this briefing points out, the primary way to reform the bloated, unelected House of Lords is to replace it with a fairly-elected revising chamber, with a clearly defined remit and which can speak up for the nations and regions of the whole UK."Voters are tired of seeing scandal after scandal in the Lords with no way of kicking them out. A much-smaller, more effective second chamber would help draw to a close the era of unaccountable power and bring our democracy into the st century.Bryans other key claims include concerns that the Scottish Parliament has gained additional powers in response to political pressures, which can be "curtailed as easily as they were granted".She says that while the Sewel convention established that Westminster would not legislate on devolved issues without the express consent of the Scottish Parliament, "we have seen from the repatriation of powers through Brexit that this may not always be adhered to".She also states that local government in Scotland has lost powers to increasing centralisation by the Scottish Government.Nancy Platts, co-ordinator of Politics for the Many ndash the trade union campaign for political reform ndash said: ldquoThis is a fundamental step [forward] in developing Labourrsquos thinking on constitutional reform. Labour must now adopt these proposals as the starting point to ensuring that our politics works for the many, not an unelected few.The report will be unveiled at a Labour fringe meeting titled: "Remaking the state: Transforming Scotland for Worker and Citizen Power".Mass poll by BMG for ERS. Fieldwork dates: August and September , from [online] surveys of  adults, GB. Data is weighted to be demographically representative. Excluding lsquodonrsquot knowsrsquo, the valid sample size is  GB adults.bull Con  %bull Lab  %bull LD  %bull UKIP  %bull Green  %bull SNP  %

title: yes-digital-chief-criticises-wings-over-scotland-and-cybernats-over-indyref
story: In an interview for a BBC documentary, Stewart Kirkpatrick said that ldquoexpletive littered rants from Wings Over Scotland were ldquoreally not helpful.He added that the so-called ldquocybernats- online Nationalists who round on critics of the SNP and independence - ldquounequivocally hurt his cause.Entitled lsquoYes No ndash Inside The Indyrefrsquo, the three part series on the  referendum was made by Paul Mitchell, whose previous work includes lsquoInside Obamarsquos White Housersquo and lsquoThe Death of Yugoslaviarsquo.The first part, screened last week, focused on the deal struck between the Scottish and UK Governments which paved the way for a plebiscite.The second instalment, which will be broadcast this week, contains exclusive interviews with key players on the two head-to-head debates between Alex Salmond and Alistair Darling, who was chair of the pro-UK Better Together.It also concentrates on the influence of social media in helping both sides get their message across to voters.The Yes Scotland campaign was regarded as having an impressive social media offering, but critics believed the official messaging was undermined by the aggression of the cybernats.Wings over Scotland, a website run by Bath-based Stuart Campbell, became a popular resource for some pro-independence supporters who were frustrated with newspapers and the BBC.However, some of Campbellrsquos output also frustrated figures in the Yes movement who believed it turned off floating voters.In an interview for the documentary, Stewart Kirkpatrick, who was Yes Scotlands head of digital, said that a Wings pamphlet on independence had been a ldquostroke of genius, but said:ldquoThe impact of Wings  Are we talking about the Wings over Scotland who is the data-driven journalist, who gets to the annoying nugget and writes a piece around it and canrsquot be argued with  Or is it the guy who refers to Tory politicians as troughing scum and goes on expletive littered rants on Twitter  This guy was very helpful, this guy really wasnrsquot.Speaking generally, he added: ldquoThe cybernat thing definitely hurt us. Unequivocally. People being abusive online did not help the Yes campaign.Campbell was also interviewed and spoke about why he set up Wings over Scotland: ldquoVery early on I realised how bad the newspaper coverage was, how bad the tv coverage was.He also said: ldquoOther countries, independence campaigns, have waded knee deep in blood. All we did was occasionally call each other some names on Twitter. The idea that Scottish people are shocked by a few swear words is laughable.Meanwhile, the documentary also revealed the anguish of Salmondrsquos key advisers after they watched their boss perform badly in the first debate with Darling.Salmond was expected to win the debate, but he noseed after focusing on what he regarded as Unionist scare stories about outer space and Scots having to drive on the right hand side of the road.Geoff Aberdein, who was Salmondrsquos chief of staff, said he was ldquodevastated by the performance: ldquoI walked into an adjacent auditoriumhellip.and just put my head in my hands for a good forty minutes.Kevin Pringle, who was Salmondrsquos trusted spin doctor, added: ldquoIt just didnrsquot really work terribly well.Salmond, in his own interview, admitted making a ldquomistake, adding: ldquoItrsquos like having a great idea last thing at night. Itrsquos less a good idea in the morning.However, Salmond performed better in the second debate and was judged to have beaten Darling.

title: macaroni-and-ice-cream-a-match-made-in-heaven
story: The art deco cafeacute, on the seafront at Largs, with its vanilla ice frontage, is a national institution. It was a family one for more than  years, but the ice cream war between brothers Aldo and Peter Nardini, feuding over the business and its direction, led to court cases, bitter accusations of treachery, plummeting fortunes and the shutters finally going up on the place, the familyrsquos heritage sadly melting away. Aldo Nardini died in , his brother Peter, the previous year. They had never properly reconciled.Only the name remained when Guiseppe lsquoSeprsquo Mirini and David Equi took the business out of receivership, revamped the interior and reopened after four years. Now they, too, have split, although itrsquos not about ldquoice cream dferences, it is stressed, but pursuing their separate businesses. Mirini owns the Tony Macaroni chain, Equi the eponymous Hamilton-based ice cream company.The two were joint owners of Nardinirsquos, but Mirini is now sole shareholder through his company Italgelat, although Equi remains a director. A spokesperson for Mirini stressed that the parting was perfectly amicable and that the two men remain good friends. Equi is in America and out of contact.Nardinirsquos has its roots in the Tuscan town of Barga, where so many emigrants to Scotland come from. In , Pietro Nardini arrived in Scotland with his family. After years of peddling round the country selling from a suitcase, he saved enough to open, in , the Largs cafeacute.It served food, too, but it was the ice cream created there from a secret family recipe which put the place on the map.Nardinirsquos heyday was in the s and early s when hordes of Glaswegians and others from further afield, in flat caps and best dresses, would go lsquodoon the watterrsquo, by train or ferry, to queue for a seat and taste the award-winning ice cream. What started as a humble cafeacute grew into a large space, an ice cream factory and a restaurant. Each weekend it would serve , gallons of ice cream, five tonnes of potatoes and  stone of haddock to holidaymakers.In the s, when cheap package holidays took off, the slide began. It was now being run by Pietrorsquos grandsons, Aldo and Peter, and they struggled to keep the business in the black.The two brothers could hardly have been more dferent. Aldo was tall, handsome and fit ndash the local paper dubbing him ldquothe Sean Connery of Largs ndash whereas Peter was shorter, a heavy smoker with a heart condition.In , they hired a non-family member, a friend of Peterrsquos, to turn round the ailing company, but it soon became clear that there were familial dferences over the appointment. David Hendry was a local businessman, who had built a fortune from a chain of funeral parlours and, to the brothers, at that time, he seemed to be the only hope to stop the family firm spiralling into bankruptcy.Three cousins, and fellow board members with the Nardini name, started legal moves to stop the appointment, but in what was the first of the internecine battles they failed and were quickly purged.The Hendry regime was initially successful and the business seemed to have turned the corner until the brothers fell out over future direction. The plan, resisted by Aldo, was to franchise the Nardini name to  cafeacutes and challenge new brands like Haumlagen-Dazs and Ben  Jerryrsquos, by selling Nardini ice cream through supermarkets.Aldo was implacably opposed. He said that while the firm wouldnrsquot make the profits of yesteryear ldquoit was still a good businessyou retained the family presence. The dference split the brothers. Peter owned  per cent of Nardinirsquos andAldo wasnrsquot coming with it, then he was going. In May  Aldo was removed from the board. He said that he was deeply shocked when his brother lted his hand to vote against him.Aldo set up his own business, Il Caffe Casa, but the family fallout took another corrosive turn which ended in the two brothers facing each other in court. Peter accused his brotherrsquos company of misleading customers into believing they were eating Nardinirsquos ice cream from Largs. The sherf ruled for Aldo but the ide was now unbridgeable.Aldorsquos daughter, the actress Daniela Nardini, stood by his side, fiercely and vocally loyal. She said: ldquoI would quite like to throw a stone through the window [of Nardinirsquos]hellipThe business has been taken over. It is just our name and our reputation.In , with debts of pound. million, Nardinirsquos went into receivership. Aldo revealed his sorrow.ldquoI am absolutely heartbroken. I said when David Hendry was brought into the company that running a funeral parlour was dferent to running an ice cream parlour. Sadly I am right. I have had no control over the company in recent years, as I had just a small share. The company is worth nothing ndash so I have lost nothing. But my children have lost what they should have inherited my grandfatherrsquos heart would break.The Nardinirsquos had lost control of their empire and only the name would survive . In , Marini and Equi formed a consortium to bring the cafeacute back and after four years, along with a pound.m refit of the listed building under the eye of Scottish Natural Heritage, Nardinirsquos reopened.The two partners opened another Nardinirsquos in Glasgowrsquos Byres road but a fortnight ago a lsquoto letrsquo sign was slapped on the window and a poster promising a refurbishment was removed. It had closed its doors just after Christmas, promising to reopen in the spring.The company had been embroiled in a planning dispute with the city council over change of use. A retrospective application for a cafeacute was rejected last year. The outlet had seemed to be popular, with queues out of the door in summer, but when it went down the blame was put on high rents.In recent years, the chain had also opened Nardinirsquos premises in Edinburgh and St Andrews as part of the firmrsquos expansion plans, but they have also since closed.This month a Nardini trading company in which Marini and Equi were directors , NOL Realisations ndash formerly Nardinirsquos of Largs ndash went into liquidation. According to liquidator Ian Wright there were no assets, only stock and cash. Lenders to the company ndash including the Bank of Scotland and the Royal Bank ndash as principal creditors, are unlikely to receive much of the loans they made.Nardinirsquos of Largs in now a branch of the Tony Macaroni empire, Viva Italia. Sep Marini, now the sole owner of the business, promised ldquoitrsquos business as usual for the restaurant in Largs going forward.Business, for Nardinirsquos in the past, has been anything but usual. Who would risk predicting the next turn in the ice cream saga ITrsquoS a -minute sail from Largs to Cumbrae, a mile away across the Clyde, and from one of the window tables inside the cafeacute you can watch the CalMac ferry the Loch Shira come and go, while the waitresses, in black aprons, skirt or trousers and white shirts, ply you with coffee, scones or, of course, ice cream.When the actress Daniela Nardini was still a child she scooped ice cream for her dad Aldo in the cafeacute foyer. Although there was a major refit when Sep Mirini and David Equi took over, it remains true to the style of the old deacutecor, one that Daniela would recognise, although she probably hasnrsquot been inside since her father lost the business in the bitter dispute with his brother Peter. What has changed is the Italian restaurant specialising in pizzas, the Tony Macaroni addition, at a right angle to the frontage along Nelson Street.The cafeacute is still bustling,nothing like the fties, middle-aged women sit around sipping their morning coffee, in a space which can cater for , the light from the panoramic windows facing the water reflected off the mirrored glass over the bar area and onto the cutlery and the monogrammed cups and saucers. If you turn your head away from the quay view, a large, metal statue of a stocky Viking dominates, with his eyes focused on the inside of the cafeacute. It marks the Battle of Largs in , the last one between the kingdoms of Scotland and Norway.In , when Aldo was still at primary school, Prime Minister Winston Churchill, General Dwight Eisenhower, later to become US President, and Lord Mountbatten were spotted coming and going at the nearby Hollywood Hotel, which had been taken over by the military. They were holding secret meetings to plan the D-Day invasion of Normandy. Legend has it, whether true or not, that they ordered takeaway ice creams from Nardinirsquos.When Nardinirsquos opened in  a bandstand was included, with a six-piece orchestra playing from it and a male crooner moved around the tables serenading the girls. Then you could get a carry-out fish supper for sixpence, today yoursquoll have little change from a tenner. The cafeacute still serves the famous Knickerbocker Glory which, to day trippers in the early sixties, cost  D. It may be less popular today, not least because the ice cream, fresh fruit, cream, nuts and chocolate sauces, will set you back pound..

title: snp-to-push-for-power-to-hold-second-independence-referendum
story: Westminster leader Ian Blackford insisted the people of Scotland should be able to "determine their own destiny"the UK leaves the EU.His party will table an amendment in the Commons today, calling for the power to hold another legally-binding vote.:Nicola Sturgeon rejects wildcat IndyrefIt comes as Theresa May faces a series of crunch votes over her Brexit deal and a possible extension of the March  deadline.Mr Blackford told the BBCs Sunday Politics Scotland: ldquoWe will be putting down an amendment this week.ldquoIt will be reflecting on what happened in the Scottish Parliament and in the Welsh Assembly this week simultaneously."There was a motion that came in front of both Parliaments that recognised that Theresa Mayrsquos deal and no-deal are not good for Scotland.ldquoWhat wersquore going to do is put down an amendment asking for the Government to recognise that Scotland voted to Remain."Wersquore also putting down, as part of that amendment, a recognition thatthe UK does leave the European Union, the people of Scotland should be able to determine their own destiny.ldquoAnd in particular they should have the power to have an independence referendumwe so choose and wersquore making reference in that to the Claim of Right in the debate we had in Parliament in July  when Parliament accepted the motion that sovereignty rests with the Scottish people."So we will do what we can to work with other parties to stop Brexit, we have no desire to see Scotland dragged out against its will, but we need to recognise thatthat does happen then the people of Scotland have got to determine their own future."He added: "There is no such thing as a good Brexit, we know that its going to cost jobs, we know that its going to impact living standards, we know of course that no deal is absolutely disastrous for the people of Scotland.": Leonard: Labour government would block IndyrefLast week, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said the Prime Minister would ldquoof course refuse the Scottish Government permission to hold another legally-binding referendum.Nicola Sturgeon has already ruled out holding a so-called ldquowildcat vote without Westminsterrsquos go-aheadMPs will vote on Mrs Mayrsquos Brexit deal on Tuesday. If it is defeated again, they will get the chance to vote against leaving the EU without a deal and in favour of extending the Brexit deadline.Mr Blackford said the SNP will vote to rule out a no-deal Brexit and extend the Article  process.But Scottish Conservative MP David Duguid branded his comments "another desperate stunt and insisted it was further evidence the SNPrsquos only priority is independence.He said: "It proves once again that the main goal for the SNP throughout the entire Brexit process has been to try to agitate for a second independence referendum."Their motives are completely transparent, and rather than putting the interests of Scotland first, theyre only promoting their narrow-minded agenda."Scots decisively voted No in  and the answer is still the same - its time the SNP recognised that."Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, said the SNP is ldquosimply using Brexit as a political tool for its latest attempt to break up the United Kingdom.She added: ldquoThe Nationalists are only interested in iding the country and holding an unwanted second independence referendum.ldquoIan Blackford and his MPs should listen to the people of Scotland who know we are stronger as part of the UK, and want the SNP to ditch the threat of a second independence referendum.Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoThe SNP seem to have learned nothing from Brexit. Constitutional upheaval brings chaos and economic damage.ldquoWe shouldnrsquot compound the damage of leaving the EU by splitting from the U.K. which is responsible for four times more trade with Scotland.:Nicola Sturgeon rejects wildcat IndyrefldquoEven Theresa May has admitted that no Brexit is still a serious possibility. The SNP should be campaigning to keep the whole of the UK in the EU, not another isive and unwanted independence referendum.A UK Government spokesman said: "Scotland had an independence referendum in  and voted decisively to remain in the UK."The Scottish Government needs to stop using Brexit as an excuse to pursue their unwanted independence agenda."Rather than constantly seeking ision and constitutional upheaval, the Scottish Government needs to work with the UK Government to avoid a damaging no deal. That is what people and business in Scotland expect."

title: 11-year-old-pupil-takes-to-world-stage-to-sound-climate-change-alarm
story: From tracking the footprints of animals to snorkelling in the sea, the wildle and environment surrounding his home in Ullapool in Wester Ross has been a vital part of his le.But a few years ago, Finlay began to worry about the future of the planet with growing media concerns about issues such as plastic pollution and global warming.He said: ldquoI have been interested in nature since I was very young because I watched wildle programmes and that was what sparked my imagination."When I got a bit older I used to go on a lot of walks trying to track animals with their prints and I went snorkelling in the sea.ldquoThen I started to hear that the planet was getting warmer and that we were polluting it with plastic and I started to get concerned, but I didnrsquot think we could do anything about it.Last summer, Finlay heard about the climate change protests of -year-old Swedish environmental activist Greta Thunberg, who skipped school to raise awareness about the planet.Her demands for the Swedish government to reduce carbon emissions gained worldwide attention and she began to inspire thousands of pupils across the world.Hearing about her work made Finlay decide to take similar action himself, becoming one of the first pupils in the UK to hold a weekly hour-long strike outside his primary school from December th.ldquoI heard about Greta through Facebook and I was impressed with what she was doing and I thought it could make a dference, he said.ldquoI decided to do my own strike outside the school. I spoke to my parents and the school about it and they were very supportive.ldquoIt started off with me, my sister Ella and her best friend Megan. We stood outside the school with placards to raise awareness about the problems the planet is facing.Finlay has been a little disappointed his protests have not spread quite as widely as he had hoped, but now he has an opportunity to take his message to the world stage.Green parties at the European Parliament in Strasbourg want young activists from around the world to attend a climate change debate on Wednesday and then speak to the media about their concerns afterwards.Finlay is the only protestor to have been chosen from Scotland and is one of only three from the UK to join pupils from countries across the world including Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, France, Germany, Hungary, Iran, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Latvia, Lithuania and the Netherlands.ldquoWe wanted more and more people to join us from the school, which hasnrsquot really happened, and we hoped it would spread across the UK, which again hasnrsquot quite happened yet, he said.ldquoA bunch of kids at my school sometimes have a laugh at me or shout things at me. I get over it, but it is frustrating because everyone needs to understand that climate change will have an impact on all of us and some people donrsquot care.ldquoThe problem is pure habit and human beings doing the things they have always done evenit is damaging the planet.ldquoIt is also a human habit to wait until the last second to do something about it. We are not quite at that last second, but we are getting there soon and need to start taking action. Everyone can make a dference.Finlayrsquos father, Geoff, who is also going on the trip, backed his sonrsquos action.He said: ldquoWe have always been very supportive and proud of what he is doing because it is a major issue for his generation.ldquoWe have been talking about this since the s and we just havenrsquot done anything about it and the message needs to be heard.Last week, councils were urged not to punish pupils for leaving school to take part in climate change strikes - as long as they have permission from their parents.Scottish Green politicians have written to councils across the country urging them to support pupils who want to take part in the next day of action on th March.An estimated , people took part in a wave of climate strikes across the UK in February, inspired by Greta.The worldwide action follows a UN climate summit in Poland which agreed rules for implementing an agreement which aims to keep global warming as close to .C as possible by .However, the world remains on track for C of warming by the target date, which scientists says will bring catastrophic extreme weather resulting in mass extinctions of animals and the destruction of crops and flooding.

title: scots-urged-to-make-attorney-plan-as-dementia-rates-soar
story: Fears are growing that people are sleepwalking into old age without a safety net to ensure their welfare and finances are properly managed should they no longer be able to look after themselves.Granting someone power of attorney to make important decisions well in advance of any downturn in mental capacity is a solution.However, itrsquos thought many Scots are either unaware of the benefits or are avoiding making formal arrangements because they fear it could be ldquotempting fate.There are also concerns among some that handing over control of their most sensitive affairs leaves them open to abuse.Now, however, there are increasing calls among experts for people to overcome their worries ndash or face the risk of having their welfare and financial wellbeing left in the hands of strangers.It comes amid rising rates of dementia: almost , Scots were diagnosed in -.As the Scottish population ages at a signicant rate, the number with dementia is predicted to rise by  per cent in the next  years.A host of other conditions can also impact on a personrsquos ability to retain full mental control over their care and finances at any age, including accidents, brain damage resulting from tumours or haemorrhages, strokes and Parkinsonrsquos Disease.More than , Scots are affected by Parkinsonrsquos Disease, with about  people diagnosed every week in  in Scotland.Itrsquos predicted the number diagnosed will double over the next  years as the population grows and ages.Dementia expert Professor June Andrews, adviser to the Dementia Services Development Trust, says there is deepening concern that many people are leaving themselves at risk of an uncertain future by failing to plan ahead and arrange powers of attorney to cover both their welfare and finances.ldquoA power of attorney saysyou canrsquot speak, are no longer making sense, or the doctors say you no longer have the capacity to take care of your own affairs, then this is what you want to be done on your behalf, she said.ldquoSome people donrsquot do it because they donrsquot see the point, and others are superstitious and think something bad will happen because they have thought about it.ldquoThey should ask themselves what is the worst thing that can happen  The worst thing would be for strangers to be making decisions about their finances and welfare without them having any influence. They should realise power of attorney takes that fear away.The Office of the Publicin Scotland looks after applications for powers of attorney and handles investigations into concerns over misuse.According to Sandra McDonald, former Publicfor Scotland, fears that the powers may be abused are often unfounded. Some % of attorneys appointed to care for inidualrsquos finances or welfare work hard and fulfil their task without complaint.Of the remaining % whose actions may prompt an investigation, just % ndash roughly , attorneys a year in Scotland ndash are found to have taken advantage of their role.She says there are steps people can take to limit the risk of any power of attorney being misused and to give them peace of mind. ldquoPeople should think carefully about what they want and the powers they want to hand over, and do it early, she said.Ian Macdonald, partner and head of private client at Wright, Johnston  Mackenzie LLP, said: ldquoGranting a power of attorney is a relatively straightforward process and can be done quickly and inexpensively.ldquoIf a person loses capacity before a power of attorney is granted and circumstances arise where that person requires assistance in managing their affairs, the options available are complicated, expensive and time consuming.Scotland is leading the way on how powers of attorney are handled, with increasing interest in the Scottish model from other countries, said Adrian Ward, convener of the Law Society of Scotlandrsquos Mental Health and Disability Subcommittee.He said: ldquoWe think nothing of insuring a house against fire, but they are far more likely to need someone to look after their affairsthey canrsquot, than see their home go up in flames.

title: one-third-of-scots-are-facing-a-pensions-time-bomb
story: Experts warn that many Scots could end up poverty-stricken after stopping work and have called for more guidance to be put in place to help people plan ahead for their later years.According to a new survey, more than half of Scots do not have any plans to financially support themselves in retirement ndash despite  per cent of those asked saying the state pension will not be enough.The research, by polling firm Censuswide Scotland, also showed that even those with private pensions are worried about the future, with one- third saying they do not believe it will be able to support them.Age Scotland described the findings as ldquoworrying, while Citizens Advice Scotlandsaid it was vital that Scots seek advice on planning for the future.CAS policy manager Mike Holmyard said: ldquoToo many people are at risk of living in or close to poverty when they retire. Less generous pension schemes have to stretch further as people are living for longer post-retirement.ldquoAuto-enrolment is welcome, but will not solve the basic problem of low levels of pension saving.ldquoWe would urge everyone to seek free, impartial and confidential advice from their local Citizens Advice Bureau, so they can make informed choices and plan effectively for their retirement.Mr Holmyard added that CAS is also becoming more aware of people dipping into their pension pots while working as a result of falling into debt.ldquoOur advisers are also increasingly hearing from people who are considering accessing their pension funds to solve debt problems, at the expense of their retirement income, which of course brings the risk of long-term financial problems, he said.Age Scotland argued that Scots should be offered a ldquocareer MOT at age  to allow them to ldquomake informed choices about training, pensions provision and future career options.Brian Sloan, chief executive of the charity, said: ldquoRight now more than half of older people age  and over have not retired because they arenrsquot ready to stop working.ldquoHowever, itrsquos worrying to hear that more than six out of  Scots donrsquot think their state pension will financially support them through retirement and that more than half do not have any plans to financially support themselves through retirement.ldquoTherersquos a clear need for more guidance to help people plan ahead for their working le and retirement.Mr Sloan added that the number of older workers is increasing faster in Scotland than the rest of the UK and called for employers to do more to support them.ldquoIt makes sense to invest in older workers, who bring a wealth of experience and skills and can provide valuable mentoring to younger generations, he said.The new full state pension is currently pound. per week, however the actual amount you get depends on your national insurance record.Under current UK Government plans, the state pension age will eventually extend to  for both men and women.However, the Censuswide survey showed that  per cent of Scots believe it will continue to increase beyond this.The data also revealed that more than a quarter of Scots do not have a private pension, with this breaking down into  per cent of men, compared to  per cent of women.Of those Scots who do have plans in place to support themselves financially in retirement, the majority plan to use savings to fund their lestyle, while others plan to sell their homes or other assets.Jordan Ferguson, of Censuswide Scotland, said: ldquoOur research indicates that Scots, of all ages, have growing number of concerns about their retirement.ldquoThe younger respondents polled seemed apprehensive that retirement age would continue to increase.ldquoWhile older respondents raised a number issues around financing their retirement.

title: john-mcdonnell-independent-group-of-mps-have-become-completely-irrelevant
story: John McDonnell branded the decision of eight of his partyrsquos MPs to leave and form The Independent Groupldquoabsolutely bizarre, and warned any support for them risked handing power to the Tories.It came as he announced a Labour Government would create , new jobs in Scotland as part of a ldquogreen industrial revolution which would see hundreds of wind turbines constructed north of the Border.Addressing a fringe meeting at the Scottish Labour conference in Dundee, Mr McDonnell said he was ldquodisappointed and to a certain extent perplexed that Labour MPs had left the party for TIG, which is made up of  pro-Remain MPs.:John McDonnell says Labour is preparing for GovernmentHe said one of the main reasons they gave was Labourrsquos failure to support a Peoplersquos Vote. However, the partyrsquos Brexit approach was decided at its conference, he said, and the week after the MPs left it backed a public vote.ldquoSo it just seemed completely futile that they left for that reason, he added. He later said: ldquoFor them to walk out at this stage I just found bizarre, absolutely bizarre.Mr McDonnell said the move would end up being ldquonot just a waste of time for them personally, but also any others who support them as well.Rejecting claims there was a major schism in his party, he said: ldquoThey are a group of people who for some reason, Irsquom not completely sure why, were disgruntled, [and] chose an issue to leave the party on. Within a week that issue was no longer relevant, I donrsquot think. I just find it a futile gesture.He added: ldquoThe Independent Group is looking increasingly completely irrelevant.ldquoIrsquove not found in the meetings that Irsquove been doing that people are even talking about them anymore.He said ldquonot one of his constituents had raised it, adding: ldquoI think theyrsquove become irrelevant very, very quickly.The shadow chancellor said those who had left Labour ldquoneed to think about the responsibility that they have, becausethey are taking votes away from Labour, it wonrsquot mean that they get elected, it wonrsquot mean there will be a TIG government ndash it will mean the Tories go back into power. He added: ldquoAnd I think thatrsquos the responsibility that some people who may have been thinking of supporting them need to think hard about.Mr McDonnell made the comments at a fringe meeting before addressing delegates from the main conference stage on Sunday.:John McDonnell attacks lsquorip-offrsquo privatised electricity marketHe vowed a Labour Government would deliver , new well-paid and unionised jobs for Scotland as part of plans to massively expand employment in the green energy sector.He said: ldquoLabour has developed ambitious plans for expanding onshore wind. At least  per cent of that new capacity will be here and could mean , new jobs in Scotland.ldquoWith another  gigawatts of capacity under Labour from offshore wind, thatrsquos another , jobs in Scotland. And when we roll out our UK-wide home retrofitting programme, that could be close to another , more jobs in Scotland.He earlier told the BBC he welcomed a potential investigation into complaints of anti-Semitism in Labour, as he wanted the party to be a ldquoshining example in how it tackles such issues.

title: from-the-gorbals-to-the-39-steps-can-we-learn-to-love-john-buchan-again
story: The fame of the man who wrote the book is just as complicated. When he died in , John Buchan was given a state funeral and was revered as a novelist, scholar, politician, publisher, war correspondent and imperial proconsul, but, as with many other great Victorian figures, there has since been a reassessment. Was Buchan just a ldquoScotsman on the make out to use his connections to get on  Was he anti-Semitic  Was he racist  His granddaughter Ursula Buchan has set out to give her answers to those questions in a new biography Beyond The  Steps and, as the title suggests, she also wants to remind us there was more to John Buchan than his most famous book.One of the most surprising episodes in the new biography is Buchanrsquos experiences in the Gorbals as a child. If we think of Buchan, we probably think of him as a slightly grand Victorian figure, but his childhood was anything but. His father was a minister at the John Knox Free Church in the Gorbals and John went to school in the area, at Hutchesonrsquos on Crown Street, where he came to know the population and their problems. Many years later, he featured a gang of Gorbals schoolkids, the Diehards, in one of his novels, Huntingtower, and Ursula Buchan is convinced his time in Glasgowrsquos most notorious slum had a profound effect on him.ldquoIt had a huge influence, she says. ldquoThough Huntingtower, which is the first book where the Gorbals Diehards appear, doesnrsquot come out until the s, hersquos remembering his walking through the Gorbals to school every day. And, also, when he went to Glasgow University, he walked everywhere so this was the Glasgow he knew and of course because his father was a minister in the Gorbals, he was brought up knowing about what it was like to be poor and I think that was huge for him. He never forgot it and it was one of the reasons he could get on with anybody ndash he could walk with kings but never lost the common touch.The other extraordinary thing about Buchanrsquos time at Glasgow University, and then Oxford, was his capacity for work ndash something that never left him. He was studying for a classics degree, but he was also writing short stories, articles for The Glasgow Herald about what it was like to be a student, and a history of Brasenose College. A journalist at the time noticed Buchan and called him a ldquomiracle of precocity. Mind you, the journalist also said that there was no sign that he would ever do much in fiction.Read more: the men and women of Scotland who made a stand against warTo be fair, that was pretty much true until The  Steps was published in  when Buchan was . It was an immediate success and even now,  years on, you can see why: Hannay is hugely likeable, the prose is pacey, and Ursula Buchan believes the modern novel of espionage would not have developed along the same lines without it. Certainly, both Graham Greene and Ian Fleming acknowledged their debt to him.However, Ursula Buchan does get slightly frustrated that the story of her grandfather has become pretty much all about The  Steps. ldquoThatrsquos why I called my book Beyond the  Steps, she says. ldquoI knew I had to have it in there somewhere but he wrote that book in six weeks when he was ill to amuse himself because hersquod run out of thrillers. He never made any literary claims for it, but he realised he could make some money.Ursula Buchan believes her grandfatherrsquos real legacy lies in the fact that he lived a good and useful le and says she has tried her best to emulate it in her own work as a gardening journalist and writer. But just look at the list of what he did and you can see how hard that would be: he wrote more than  books, he was an MP, he was a publisher in Edinburgh, he was Governor General of Canada, he worked as a journalist during the First World War and wrote a -volume history of it. He also worked as an administrator in South Africa on improving the conditions in the concentration camps that had been set up by the British Army to accommodate Boer prisoners. The conditions at the time were a scandal and Buchan managed to get the death rate down by improving sanitation and water supplies.ldquoPeople donrsquot understand that the concentration camp in South Africa is not the same as an extermination camp in Germany, says Ursula Buchan, ldquobut they werenrsquot nice places and when the civil authorities took them away from Kitchener and the military, they were absolutely horried by the death toll. The army werenrsquot, I donrsquot think, actively cruel but itrsquos not what armies do ndash they donrsquot know how to look after civilian populations.ldquoBy the time John Buchan got there in October , there was already deep disquiet in Britain. That was what impelled them to turn it over to the civilian authorities and really try and do something. And they did. Within six months they had cut the death toll substantially and the protests in Britain died down.Ursula Buchan says her grandfatherrsquos approach to the camps was typical of his pragmatic views. ldquoHe was not a jingoist, she says, ldquoand he worried the Empire,clever energetic and public-spirited people didnrsquot continue to be involved with it, would decline to the detriment of everybody. In some ways, he was very much ahead of his time.Read more: The  Steps PlanIn other, more controversial ways of course, he was very much of his time and Ursula Buchan acknowledges this of her ancestor: his occasional use of the n-word, for example, or his use of language, mainly in The  Steps and the other Hannay books, that would now be considered anti-Semitic. His granddaughter points out that there are favourable depictions of Jews where in Buchanrsquos work he also supported the Balfour Declaration and in , less than three months after Hitler came to power, he was one of only  MPs who signed a motion deploring the treatment of Jews in Germany.ldquoThose were dferent days, says Ursula Buchan, ldquoand we have to be very careful about wagging a disapproving finger becausewe do that, we donrsquot allow ourselves to understand people in earlier times. We put a distance between them and us ndash lsquothey use the n word, theyrsquore deplorable, Irsquom not going to connect with these peoplersquo. Itrsquos very interesting that nobody criticised him at the time because everybody was using the same language ndash they generalised about peoples and races in a way that wersquore very much more reticent about.Ursula Buchan also has a warning for Scottish Nationalists who might seek to claim John Buchan as one of them, based mostly on his famous statement ldquoevery Scotsman should be a Scottish nationalist. In fact, Buchan was a ldquounionist nationalist who supported Scotlandrsquos place in the British union and Ursula Buchan is clear about where his loyalties lay. ldquoI donrsquot think he would have supported the modern Scottish Nationalist Party, she says firmly.As for Buchanrsquos Scottish background, his granddaughter says it is the key to understanding him and that the memory of his minister father with his poor, shabby congregation scattered round inner Glasgow influenced him hugely and drove him to push himself. Ursula also laughs about him being a hard act to follow. She never met her grandfather but having him as a relative, she says, meant writing was always considered a good and worthy thing to do.Ultimately, she would like to encourage people to read some of her grandfatherrsquos lesser-known works and find some of the gems embedded there. Such as this one about the fragility of civilisation: ldquoThere is a narrow line between the warm room and the savage out-of-doors hellip You call it miles of rampart I call the ision a line, a thread, a sheet of glass.And this one about his fears for the consequences of scientic development. Everybody in the future will be comfortable, he said, but easily distracted. ldquoTheir shallow minds would be easily bored, he said, ldquotherefore unstable. Their le would be largely a quest for amusement. In other words, John Buchan predicted the effects of the internet. It seems there was no end to his genius.Ursula Buchan is appearing at Aye Write at the Mitchell Library in Glasgow on March  at .pm. See ayewrite for more details. Beyond the Thirty-Nine Steps is published by Bloomsbury on April

title: nicola-sturgeon-facing-snp-backlash-over-currency-plans
story: George Kerevan today launched the Campaign for an Independent Currencywith a scathing attack on the First Ministerrsquos preferred plan, the controversial SNP Growth Commission.He said it meant ldquocuts to services and spending, could lead to keeping the pound ldquoindefinitely, and was ldquocompletely contrary to the Scotland that people want to build.The Commission proposed a decade of tight public spending after a Yes vote to halve Scotlandrsquos deficit, and keeping the pound until six tests were met for any new currency, earning widespreadcriticismon the left of the Yes movement.The CIC is now urging activists to stop the SNP leadershiprsquos plan to adopt the Commission as party policy at next monthrsquos conference in Edinburgh.It wants local branches to rally behind an amendment which wouldditch the Commissionrsquos ldquoarbitrary six tests for moving to a new currency so the switch couldhappen in the first term of an independent parliament.TheCIC amendment seeks to rewrite a leadership motion on the Commission tabled by Finance Secretary Derek Mackay and SNP depute leader Keith Brown.Mr Mackay has said publicly he welcomes debate around the Commission, however the SNP leadership is unlikely to be happy at the proposals being linked to cuts, something critics have said all along, but ministers have denied.:Row over SNPs currency plans for an independent ScotlandMr Kerevan, the MP for East Lothian from  to , and a persistent critic of the Growth Commission, said: ldquoWhile the motion put to conference is a positive step, it must be amended to ensure powers over currency are taken from Westminster at the nearest opportunity to be used by Scotland in the interests of Scotland.ldquoWe should not continue to chain ourselves to Westminster which has long made decisions contrary to Scotlandrsquos prosperity and will.ldquoThe Growth Commissionrsquos six tests would leave Scotland using the pound indefinitely, result in cuts to services and spending, and allow the market to dictate an independent Scotlandrsquos decisions.ldquoThis is completely contrary to the Scotland that people want to build and we should reject those tests. We need to fund our NHS, our schools, our local authorities, build infrastructure and homes. We need to build the Scotland we want and we should not give that vision up.The Commissionrsquos six tests would assess whether Scotlandrsquos economic record was credible and sustainable whether markets had faith in a new Scottish Central Bank and its ability to issue debt whether the public and business wanted it whether Scotland had adequate reserves whether it would improve trade and whether Scotlandrsquos economic cycle was ldquosignicantly out of phase with that of the rest of the UK to make it ldquofeasible and desirable.Andrew Wilson, the former SNP MSP who authored the Commission, said explaining these tests to voters before a second referendum was an ldquoabsolute necessity.But Mr Kerevan said: ldquoThe views of international markets and corporations should always fall behind that of the people. The sovereign will of the Scottish people and Parliament should be the ones to make decisions on our currency to benefit our economy.ldquoIf certainty and stability is the aim, we should not leave the creation of independent currency to be open ended. Clear and definite plans must be set to establish a independent currency in the first term of the Scottish Parliament to prevent any delay to its creation.:SNP Commission U-turned on currency, says former MPThe CIC amendment would strike out a key clause in the leaderships motion on currency.This says: ldquoConference believes that it should be the policy of an SNP government in an independent Scotland to establish an independent currency and agrees that the process and precise timescale for doing so should be subject to robust governance and guided by the six tests recommended by the Sustainable Growth Commission.:Key Sturgeon adviser urges softest possible form of Scottish independenceThe CIC proposes replacing this with: ldquoConference believes that achieving successful higher growth and securing a sustainable fiscal balance in an independent Scotland can only be achieved through the establishment of a separate Scottish currency.ldquoConference believes it should be the policy of an SNP government in an independent Scotland to establish a separate Scottish currency within the letime of the first, post-independence parliament.ldquoThe pound sterling will remain in use until the currency transition.The CIC said this would ldquoremove the requirement to end any fiscal deficit and ensure foreign lenders are satisfied with Scottish tax and spending - both of which would result in cuts.An ldquoarbitrary test on ensuring business stability would be scrapped along with the ldquoparadoxical test on ensuring there are sufficient reserves of a yet non-existent currency.There also would be no harmonising between Scotland and Englandrsquos economic cycle in an attempt to ensure decisions are made in Scotlandrsquos best interests, the campaign said.:Tom Gordon: SNPrsquos currency plan may please members, but not votersCIC spokesperson Rory Steel said: ldquoAn independent currency will allow the people of Scotland to exercise their power in an independent Scotlandrsquos economy.ldquoWe need the SNP grassroots to exercise their power now and take the amendment to their branch for approval.Labour Finance Spokesperson James Kelly said: ldquoThe SNPrsquos Growth Commission is really a cuts commission,and there is no currency plan the SNP can come up with that doesnrsquot lead to turbo charged austerity for Scotland. Thatrsquos why only Labour in Scotland is standing on an anti-austerity  offering hope and investment.TheScottish Socialist Party last week saidit would boycott any cross-party campaign in a second referendumthe Commission becomesSNP policy.Pamela Nash, chief executive of the anti-independence group Scotland in Union, said:"The SNPrsquos plan to ditch the pound and put mortgages, pensions and salaries at risk is reckless, and this splinter group now wants to impose the pain on the people of Scotland even earlier."The splits within the movement to leave the UK are growing because there is no coherent currency proposal for an independent Scotland, just like Alex Salmond found in . There is simply no better arrangement than the one we currently have as part of the UK.Tory MSPMurdo Fraser said:"This simply demonstrates the splits that run through the SNP from top to bottom.ldquoThe Finance Secretary and the SNP deputy leader have already put forward a motion to create a new Scottish currency, but that clearly isnrsquot enough for these nationalists.ldquoNicola Sturgeon knows that there is no majority for independence, but she will not be able to appease her activists for much longer.ldquoWhile the SNP continues to argue over fictional currency, Scots want action on health, education and roads now.LibDem spokesperson Wendy Chamberlain said:"In the midst of the Brexit chaos, as we face the very real danger of a no-deal exit, the SNP are focusing on their pursuit of another independence referendum.ldquoJust like Brexit, there isnrsquot a crumb of certainty about what you would actually get.ldquoThe SNP really have learned nothing from the past two years of constitutional turmoil. Breaking up is costly and hard to do.The SNP has been asked for comment.

title: when-is-brexit-vote-theresa-may-faces-another-deal-defeat
story: But, one day before MPs are due to hold another meaningful vote, Brexit negotations between Theresa May and the EU remain deadlocked.The Prime Ministerremains locked in talks with European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker after failing to find a breakthrough over the weekend.Talks will continue today,with the aim of securing changes to the deal before tomorrow, but a lack of progress threatens to derail a week of crucial votes.Read more:Theresa May fights to save Brexit plan amid warnings of another crushing defeatTheresa Mays deal is currently scheduled to face a "meaningful vote" in Parliament on Tuesday.If the Prime Ministers deal isrejected again, a further vote was promised for Wednesday on whether the UK should leave without a deal.As talks in Brussels stall again, the government is reportedly expected to try and water down Tuesdays vote to a provisional one.Theresa Mays Brexit deal has already been rejected by MPs, suffering the largest defeat for a sitting government government in history.Read more: Humiliated Theresa May suffers biggest government defeat in historyAfter postponing the vote in December, believing she didnt have the mandate, MPs voted by  votes to  to reject Mrs Mays deal.In January it was defeated by a majority of .Right now, Theresa May faces another massive Commons defeat. Her deal has to reverse more than  votes to win approval. A last-minute breakthrough from Brussels isnt out of the question but, without any changes to the text of the deal itself, it may not be enough to persuade MPs to the back the Prime Minister.Without any steps forward, will Mrs May walk into another Commons vote when it is almost certain her deal will be voted down again  It is reported that the government will try and change the nature of tomorrows vote to be provisional instead of meaningful. But, with less than three weeks to go, voting on a hypothetical scenario wont go down well with the House.

title: theresa-may-faces-brutal-defeat-as-brexit-vote-confirmed
story: However Number  did not rule out tweaking the motion which will go before parliament to improve its chance of passing, something which itself could provoke a fiery backlash.The motion is due to be published later today for a vote on Tuesday.The latest legal advice of Attorney General Geoffrey Cox is also expected to be published.Amid reports of a devastating three-figure defeat in store, Downing Street has promised two more votes - on whether to have a no-deal Brexit, andthat is rejected a vote on whether to delay Brexit.The latter votes were originally scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday, but there is now speculation they could both be held on Wednesday.Ms May saw her withdrawal deal defeated by a record  votes in January, with Tory Brexiters rebelling over the Irish backstop provision.:Theresa May fights to save Brexit plan amid warnings of another crushing defeatDespite weeks of talks with Brussels, Mrs May has failed to secure any legally binding changes to the backstop which could placate her own side.Downing Street admitted negotiations were "deadlocked" and a phone call last night between the PM and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker failed to make a breakthrough.It is understood the day had a second call today.There is growing speculation at Westminster thatthe PM loses badly or tries to pull off yet another delay, she could be facing the end of her premiership.Former Labour minister Yvette Cooper said thatMrs May tried to pull any of the votes it would make her previous assurance to MPs a ldquostraight up lie.EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier said the talks happening now were between British politicians, rather than between the UK and Brussels.The PMs spokesman cautioned against "speculation" that Mrs May might ask Parliament to vote on a "conditional" motion expressing its readiness to support a form of deal other than the one agreed with Brussels.In a sign of Brussels frustration, European Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas said: "It is now for the House of Commons to take an important set of decisions this week."Mr Barnier told AFP as he arrived at a meeting of EU ambassadors: "We talked all weekend and now the discussions, the negotiations, are between the Government in London and the Parliament in London."Tory former minister Nick Boles said: "I am sure that the Prime Minister will honour these three commitments."If she doesnt she will forfeit the confidence of the House of Commons.":Theresa May warned Brexit defeat lsquoinevitablersquo without changes to the backstopMrs May has been told by Brexiteers that rejection of the Withdrawal Agreement is "inevitable" unless there are signicant changes to the Northern Ireland backstop.Some called on the PM to postpone the meaningful vote rather than risk another damaging reverse and instead table a "conditional" motion setting out the terms for dealing with the backstop issue which Parliament would be prepared to accept.Jacob Rees-Mogg, chairman of the pro-Brexit Tory European Research Group, told the Times it "would not be a foolish way to proceed".He added: "I think a meaningful vote with an addendum saying this House will support a dealsuch and such is done might be a way of uniting the party or limiting the scale of the defeat."Former chief whip Andrew Mitchell told the paper: "Anything that avoids what looks like a massive defeat on Tuesday is worth considering."Former Cabinet minister Nicky Morgan said Mrs Mays position would become untenableParliament "dismantled" her Brexit policy in a series of votes during the course of the week.Askedthe PM had considered resigningher deal was defeated on Tuesday, her spokesman said he had not discussed the matter with Mrs May, but added: "I have seen nothing at all to suggest that.":When is Brexit vote: Theresa May faces another deal defeatTory MP George Freeman said Mrs May should quit after Brexit rather than have a "panicked change of leader now", telling BBC Radio s Today programme: "I hope the Prime Minister can get withdrawal through and then I do think we need to choose a new leader for a new generation with a new vision of a conservativism that can make sense of Brexit and reinspire and reunite the nation."Environment Secretary Michael Gove - one of the leaders of the official Leave campaign in the referendum - became the latest Cabinet minister to urge MPs to vote for Mrs Mays deal.In an article for the Daily Mail, he said: "I hope that everyone who believes in our democracy - in the importance of delivering Brexit, but also in the critical need to unite our country - will come behind the Prime Ministers deal this week."

title: 4 000 aberdeenshire homes take up satellite broadband option
story: A # million investment by Aberdeenshire Council in the region#s broadband network has seen major strides made in terms of improved services.Councillors were told at Thursday’s full authority meeting that , homes had since taken up a satellite option to access a better service.Much of the money was pumped into an extension of the fibre network, but the challenging topography and rurality of the Shire saw a big take up in the satellite system.Infrastructure services chief Stephen Archer told councillors that more than , premises would be able to access fibre in the region which would offer a “signicant benefit and improvement” over existing services.He said: “Fibre is where we need to go because other technologies are neither cost-effective nor fully evolved and developed to allow us to put in robust connectivity across Aberdeenshire.”With some ,km of fibre now laid under the latest scheme, Mr Archer described it is a “celebration of success”, but stressed that pockets of Aberdeenshire still suffered from poor connectively – often still suffering with dial-up speeds.While welcoming the results so far, council leader Jim Gford said there was still a long way to go to support North-east communities.He said: “There are still far too many properties in many places that don’t have decent – and in some cases any – broadband and that’s a piece of work we have to keep moving forward.”Aberdeenshire Council’s contribution of £m was the largest local authority contribution to the programme.Work is continuing on installations in Aberdeenshire and is likely to run until
